You may be right about Patriarchal and Feminism thinking. But the problem lies in the demands in implementing feminism. They do not want equal rights but the more advantages for females and to remove disadvantages. Nothing is wrong in this but only when things are done keeping in mind both genders. 

When one advantage becomes disadvantage for other gender , it cannot be called feminism, but it is happening in the name of feminism.

1. Like reservation in colleges, govt jobs, even in private jobs. It is like earlier men have taken advantages in these places now let women do. Instead of equal rights and opportunity , they want to take upperhand.
2. Like equal pay for men and women cricket teams even though they don't generate same revenue. If this logic is applied everywhere then it will disrupt the society. For example , Instagram influencers, where a girl attracts many followers by showing only curves and eventually more revenue by ads etc but boy cannot. Shouldn't the 'equal pay' logic be applied here? 
3. Like laws made to prevent cruelty on women have now became a tool to exploit innocent men. If things were done keeping both genders in mind then this would not happen. 

I can tell you innumerous examples where they have demanded upper hand instead of equality and in most cases they have been granted.
It might have helped some of the poor, needy girls or women but the number is less and the biggest beneficiary are the girls who have decent financial background or above. They have all the resources and accesses as men do but they have been granted upper hands in many places and now they exploit men same like men used to do when they had upper hand in the society. 

In nut shell , innocent men and women are still suffering. The difference is that earlier evil minded men used to exploit and now both evil minded men and women exploit according to their comfort.

Men and women are made as equals in the eyes of God (in terms of value), given their own areas of strengths and weaknesses, roles, and responsibilities. Dear Dhruv Rathe,

I hope this message finds you well. I am reaching out to you because we are in desperate need of your help.

Recently, students at our universities (Specially Dhaka University, Chittagong University and Jahangir Nagar University) has been subjected to severe torture and harassment by government officials and student political league named "CHHATRA LEAGUE". 

This situation has created an atmosphere of fear and oppression, and many of us feel powerless to change it.

We're in an authoritarian regime.

We believe that your platform could bring much-needed attention to our plight. We need strong international media coverage.

It's not limited in "quota protest" anymore. It's much more than that. 

We may regain our freedom of speech.

Your influence and ability to reach millions could help expose these atrocities and potentially bring about change. We kindly ask if you could make a video or post about our situation to shed light on what is happening here.

It's 4:15 am. And I can't sleep thinking about my brothers and sisters of Jahangir Nagar University.

I myself also was attacked by the "CHHATRA LEAGUE" yesterday at 3pm when doing a peaceful protest.
Many was injured. I escaped somehow.

I love my country. I'm not feeling safe in my own homeland.

We would be incredibly grateful if you could use your platform to help us. Your support could make a significant difference in our fight for justice and safety. People of Bangladesh are fade up with this fascist government culture.

Thank you for considering our request. Please let us know if you need any further information or if there are other ways we can assist you in covering this issue.

Sincerely,

A Bangladeshi Student from University of Chittagong.

i disagree with feminism regardless of its claims on equality. as I have noticed , it is more of man vs woman power struggle within societies. I have seen women take advantage of their freedom in western societies through family laws and property rights. They use the women rights and feminist ideologies to defend their unfair acts. I realise there can not be a society where men or women can have equal right. Reasons are:  for thousands of years most societies lived under male domination. And I agree that male took advantage of his dominance. Similarly if women were in charge of societies , They would do the same cruelty to men as men did to women. So in terms of morality men and women can be both ignorant , either of them can do injustice to each other if given opportunity. here is always competition between these 2 genders by nature somehow. Those who are married they can see this in their relationship. There is always power struggle between 2 genders. Therefore even set laws for equality , either gender will struggle to abuse those freedom and laws try to stay dominant in every matter. 
Based on their biological physical differences , it really matters in their capabilities. This is true, For example , My own elder sister was complaining that she is is unable to find job online in Australia. I was shocked. So I tried make her resume, and tried job hunting for her on my laptop. I saw most of the jobs were physically heavy work that a women can not handle them, and advertisements were asking for stronger men in order to avoid problem such as back injuries , safety issues. And there were very limited positions where jobs were available such as admin roles. Most were demanding a female for the role, some were flexible and asking for either gender. but the pay was less, not because they were asking for female but because the work was very easy. 
Say a man gets employed he would get the same pay rate as if they would employ a women. I realise that in most factories they demand for men because their physical capabilities, not because they were discriminating against women. I knew those job are not for my sister, she can not lift upto 20 kg being single or after marriage on pregnancy. Therefore the physical capability is natural fact that can not be denied. You can not compare a cat with fish and expect both to climb tree. but yes a cat has it own ability and fish has it is own importance to make this world perfect. it does not mean that one is superior upon another. This is the point where feminism has failed to understand and it is unnatural ideology.

In my opinion, men and women are made differently with biological and physical differences, but both deserve to be equally treated with equal opportunities. As all of these are important, we must respect both the genders. However, we must also encourage if a girl wants to become a pilot or become a soldier or a man wants to look after his children and do housework. Here, I didn't mean to demean any gender but to make all realise that it's not men vs women but men and women. All of us deserve to live our own way of life. And we must respect those who deserve it, irrespective of gender.

Dhruv, genders are not equal from a scientific point of view. Our developmental path is not same. Our physical ability is different. Our hormonal systems are not same. That is a biological fact. Our emotional needs are also different. There are quite a lot of scientific studies that point to women have different preferences and behavioural patterns that are not followed by men and vice versa. So if we start forcing people and their choices based on gender we are walking the wrong path. I will talk about individual choice in this context. What humanity needs is the respect for individual choice.   
But we can work for equal rights for both genders under law and policy.  Indeed, woman can work jobs, fend for their family and be equally contributory to society. The question of feminism is about equality under law, not forcing narratives like patriarchy. It is about every girl finding out for herself what is right for her and what role model she want to follow. Often they look at their mother and their experiences. The problem with 4th way feminism currently underway is that it has become toxic. It is a politicised movement in the west that has grown into become labelled as "woke" where you get to see LGBTQ+ men suddently declaring themselves as women and participate in womens sport. Suddenly these substandard athletes become the top grade. That is intellectual dishonesty. This woke movement is an agenda of the Elisitst Corporates of the west, who wanted to take advantage of the Cheap labour that women provided. 

The problem is here that a very complex topic is again presented  with lopsided statements such as mens issues can be handled by feminism. No it is because men are human beings  and we psychological distinct from woman. Stating anything else is a lie not a scientific fact. There are natural outlets for boys to vent out their emotions when growing up.That involves some rough play also. Why do you think gladiatorial sports like MMA and boxing enjoy so much popularity?  Why do you think that most popular sports amoung men are often phyiscally intensive in nature. That women sports have a fraction of the viewership of mens sport? 

In the name of patriarchy most men's issues are being politicised and painted a dark color. Isnt interesting that it is the women often talking about mens violence and issues. Why are men not being consulted? Why are men not talking about their issues. It is because we talk about it amoung men. You tube is full of content channel that talk about these issues and their audience and participation is heavily leans on men. This is because men/boys have greater propensity to men(Actors, Sportsmen, male Polticial leaders) as role models. The attempt to form groups and gangs by boys with only men in that is not abnormal. There are several scientific studies showing the need for boys and men to have peer groups and the benefits of that.

Since when did the word masculine has become associated with the word "Toxic". Everytime that word is taken up in the media it is associated with toxicity as if men and their natural state is violent, misogynist, self indulgent and irresponsible individuals. Sad state is that a large number of boys when they grow up get through a rebellious phase where they exhibit some of these traits for social acceptance or identity  establishment. Alpha male is a reality. Not a "Toxic" aboimination. Please spend some time researching the evolution of the species and the role of the Alpha male especially amoung our direct ancestors.  And the best antidote is not feminism but good father figures who are present in their lives. Help them find their own identity. Become examples for them. Mothers are important too, but for this need a father is the role model.
 
Meanwhile we all have Fathers at home.  Many can attest how they quietly take on the world, work hard,  particiapate in the well being of the family unit. Often they play an important role out in the society, spending time away from family. That often they go through the same emotional problems of stress and expectations but take on those challenges for the love of their family.  How they love their children irrespective of gender. How they are the most effected in case of divorce since they have no natural rights to child custody as women enjoy. That there is huge problem where woman in the west especially are abusing that right to cheat a There are several TED talks too about the same.

Yet the feminist almost always zooms on the few toxic  inidividual who are failed fathers. One major index to look at the number of talk shows and programmes focusing on feminism and the rights of woman. Why is age old institution like family is often pictured in a unfavourable light in the media? 

Another point to look at is the state of decline in the West and there are now big debate going on the influence of 3rd way feminism in destroying the family fabric. Over 50% of African American families are now single parent with mother in custody. And the most problem group of errant boys/men are from that group. Lawlessness, crime, drugs have overtaken most black neighbourhoods. Social scientist are talking now about how 3rd wave feminism has misguided a generation of women and men. How Liberal Socialism have created the decline of Black America

A great exercise in obfuscation. Sticking to old dictionary definitions of the term or insisting on exclusion of behaviour or attitudes which their practitioners would certainly claim arise out of them being 'feminists' does not make for a sound case. This video's transcript would make for a good bland school essay. Nothing more. Savitribai Phule is in a very old boat. Call it by whatever name, but the concern of many men and women (including Margaret Atwood) is the constant scrutiny and nagging of every small act or gesture of men. Missing a sense of proportion when condemning men's behaviour. And a perennial wish to persecute. At present, it's an exercise to grab power, Mr. Rathee. Either you are blindsided by the new hegemony or you know it and continue with the wishful thinking that 'feminism' would confine itself to the definitions you presented.

Look at the laws, and the policies governments and other organisations keep coming up with. One example, if a minor girl's 'consent' is immaterial because she is not old enough then is it fair to burden the boys with sole responsibility? Of course, case of assault is different. Are all minor boys even taught that they would be solely persecuted for any intimacy with a girl? Line must be drawn a little before. 

Animal is a bullshit film and we need to protect boys from taking any lesson from such crap. At the same time, when you corner someone and hound them until they sing your song then people react irrationally. When you push them to be either with you or against you then you are forcing them to pick the latter.

Have you heard of the phenomenon called identity politics? Most 'feminists' are fond of certain category of statistics. These are a means to an end. The end is power. Some statistics that were absent from the recent NCRB crime data: rising cases of crime by women. Of course, some women committing crime is not any worse than some men commiting crime. However, the current discourse does not let one pay attention to that. 

As for 'patriarchy': Historically the scarcity and the challenge nature presented must have called for great efficiency in social arrangement. Given women's exclusive biological function of giving birth and the associated problems they face because of this it was quite efficient to make them look after the children and the house. Men don't face these biological challenges, hence, it makes more sense for them to be outdoors, be it fighting or working. Of course, this does not mean women should be excluded from decision making, but the truth is they are not. In the 'patriarchal' set-up ask any man who do they consult when deciding what dynamics to keep with other members in joint families. Furthermore, efforts can be made that allow women to overcome these challenges to do other work. This takes us to the next point of 'equality'.

What you are doing is comparing the apples to oranges. Boys from poor or rural families also don't have, and have never had, the opportunities to that middle and upper class boys do. Equality of opportunity is not going to make all occupy higher positions. Most women, like most men, will be another brick in the wall, be it at home or in the office. Equality has also brought us quite a number of women driving e-rickshaws in Delhi. Historically, a small number of men sat on high positions, like they do today, coveted by equally educated women. Their lie is that women will share it equally if most drive rickshaws, become domestic helps, overworked desk workers, etc and some occupy decision making positions.

That is a very interesting take. Normally, people do not view feminism through this lens. But is feminism really as you claim it to be... Concepts of hyper-masculinity and matriarchy are pushed up at the thoughts of feminism... and I also wonder about one more thing.... What exactly are rights? One might say that they are objectively chosen... but is objectivity something to be supported cause who is this majority who chose these rights... or how were they brought about... and how are we so certain that they are "objective" (Note: Objectivity is something extremely modern and was non-existent in the pre-modern and the antiquity)... There are a lot of problems with feminism if we dissect it using philosophy, not that I am against it... Honestly, there is no perfect system that we humans have developed. Locke, Rousseau, Marx and others all tried their best to bring forth promising ideologies but truly none of those ideologies seem to be "promising". There is always a flaw... Just like in feminism... and the concept of genders... and the entire notion that they should all have "equal human rights"... as idealistic as it sounds... in my opinion it causes more harm than good... Of course, anyone can disagree with me...

I should stop... 3 AM thoughts hit different :)
Note: I am not against feminism... Its just that feminism is not a stand alone concept... it brings forth so many other things as baggage or societal concepts with it that it either becomes distorted or harmful.

How could you miss this famous name, Simone de Beauvoir, and her famous statement from her famous book, _The Second Sex_: 'One is not born, but becomes a woman.' It basically points out the difference between gender and sex: sex is a biological reality, but gender is a cultural construction. There is no truth as such in one's gender; you just put on your gender the way you put on your clothes. Now, the problem lies in the fact that putting on one's gender is not an innocent act; it is subject to sexual and cultural politics which creates inequality between the sexes.

With regard to the changes in these rights throughout the ages, the basic principles have not changed, but with regard to the application of these principles, there can be no doubt that during the golden age of Islam, the Muslims applied the shariâ€™ah (Islamic law) of their Lord more, and the rulings of this shariâ€™ah include honoring oneâ€™s mother and treating oneâ€™s wife, daughter, sister and women in general in a kind manner. The weaker religious commitment grew, the more these rights were neglected, but until the Day of Resurrection there will continue to be a group who adheres to their religion and applies the shariâ€™ah (laws) of their Lord. These are the people who honor women the most and grant them their rights. 

Despite the weakness of religious commitment among many Muslims nowadays, women still enjoy a high status, whether as daughters, wives or sisters, whilst we acknowledge that there are shortcomings, wrongdoing and neglect of womenâ€™s rights among some people, but each one will be answerable for himself.

And Allah knows best.

There is no need for us to mention the situation of women in Greek, Persian or Jewish society, but even Christian societies had a bad attitude towards women. The theologians even gathered at the Council of Macon to discuss whether a woman was merely a body or a body with a soul. They thought it most likely that women did not have a soul that could be saved, and they made an exception only in the case of Mary (Maryam â€“ peace be upon her). 

The French held a conference in 586 CE to discuss whether women had souls or not, and if they had souls, were these souls animal or human? In the end, they decided that they were human! But they were created to serve men only. 

During the time of Henry VIII, the English Parliament issued a decree forbidding women to read the New Testament because they were regarded as impure. 

Until 1805, English law allowed a man to sell his wife, and set a wifeâ€™s price at six pennies. 

In the modern age, women were kicked out of the house at the age of eighteen so that they could start working to earn a bite to eat. If a woman wanted to stay in the house, she had to pay her parents rent for her room and pay for her food and laundry. 

How can we compare this to Islam which enjoins honoring and kind treatment of women, and spending on them?

Islam states that the best of the Muslim men is the one who treats his wife in the best manner, and the man is forbidden to take his wifeâ€™s money without her consent. Allah says (interpretation of the meaning): 

â€œand live with them honorablyâ€ [al-Nisa 4:19] 

â€œAnd they (women) have rights similar (to those of their husbands) over them to what is reasonable, but men have a degree (of responsibility) over them. And Allah is All-Mighty, All-Wiseâ€ [al-Baqarah 2:228]

And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: â€œI urge you to treat women well.â€ (Narrated by al-Bukhari, 331; Muslim, 1468) 

And the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: â€œThe best of you is the one who is best to his wife, and I am the best of you to my wives.â€ (Narrated by al-Tirmidhi, 3895; Ibn Majah, 1977; classed as sahih by al-Albani in Sahih al-Tirmidhi)

The Truth about Feminism | Is Feminism Destroying Indian Society? | Dhruv Rathee

The video discusses the concepts of feminism and patriarchy, emphasizing that feminism aims for political, economic, and social equality between men and women.

It clarifies that feminism does not seek to give women more power than men but strives for equal rights and opportunities.

The video also highlights how patriarchal thinking impacts both men and women, leading to issues such as men's loneliness, pressure to conform to traditional gender roles, and the suppression of emotions.

It addresses the historical context of feminism and its waves, emphasizing the importance of smashing patriarchy for the benefit of both men and women.

The video also critiques the misrepresentation of feminism in certain films and social media, highlighting the need to focus on real feminist issues rather than misconceptions and stereotypes.

This video script explores the concepts of feminism and patriarchy, debunking misconceptions and highlighting the importance of gender equality. It addresses the impact of patriarchal thinking on both men and women and emphasizes the need for a society that values equal rights and opportunities for all.
Highlights
â€¢	0:00-1:26 ğŸ¬ The script introduces the topic and addresses the question of whether feminist films are bad for society.
â€¢	1:27-4:10 ğŸŒ The definitions of feminism and patriarchy are explained, emphasizing the fight for equality rather than women having more power than men.
â€¢	4:11-8:58 ğŸš» The script discusses the division between patriarchal and feminist ideologies, the social conditioning that contributes to patriarchal views, and the role of media in perpetuating regressive stereotypes.
â€¢	8:59-12:52 ğŸ‘¥ The script explores historical examples of women opposing equal rights and the existence of patriarchal thinking among some women.
â€¢	12:53-16:30 âš– The impact of patriarchal thinking on men is discussed, highlighting issues such as unemployment pressure, height-related stereotypes, and the normalization of violence.
â€¢	16:31-18:14 ğŸ˜” The script addresses menâ€™s loneliness as a consequence of patriarchal norms and societal expectations.
â€¢	18:15-19:56 ğŸ‘€ The importance of challenging patriarchal thinking and promoting gender equality is emphasized, with examples of male celebrities who openly identify as feminists.
Key Insights
â€¢	ğŸ’¡ The fight for gender equality is not a battle between men and women, but rather between patriarchal and feminist ideologies.
â€¢	ğŸ’¡ Patriarchy is a social system where men have control over women, while feminism seeks political, economic, and social equality for all genders.
â€¢	ğŸ’¡ Social conditioning plays a significant role in perpetuating patriarchal views, even among women.
â€¢	ğŸ’¡ Media, including TV serials and films, often reinforce regressive stereotypes and ideals of an â€œideal womanâ€ that conform to patriarchal norms.
â€¢	ğŸ’¡ Historical examples show that women have also opposed equal rights due to societal pressures and internalized patriarchal thinking.
â€¢	ğŸ’¡ Patriarchal thinking negatively impacts men, including pressures related to employment, height, and societal expectations of aggression.
ğŸ’¡ Challenging patriarchal norms and promoting gender equality benefits both men and women, as evidenced by male celebrities who openly identify as feminists.

I appreciate the video essay as it puts through the rational points without much fluff. I would like to add though, as what the film critics mentioned in the video talked about the 'feminist' movies, which I would wish to, by extension, expand on:
Back when I used to spend some time on my anonymous account on Twitter, I did realize there were quite a few people who basically were parodying feminism like how those 'alpha males' believe it is, while being serious too with their thoughts. And then there are also people who would just slap themselves the label of being a feminist, simply as a means to get validation (and maybe some internet romance) from other feminists, genuine or otherwise. This exactly makes me not want to identify myself as one, simply because of the self-anointing thing; like let the person's actions speak, not the person themselves. If someone else calls you one, consider it an honor, but not when you introduce yourself as one; that just adds more suspicion if one really is a feminist or just seeking validation while being irrational towards the situation.
Other than that, thank you for the video essay. I do hope it reaches more to people to really understand how they think with situations involving genders is absolutely wrong, on both ends of the spectrum. And I also wish that feminism gets its original meaning back and not be associated with matriarchy to the uninitiated, instead of them blazing guns at each other for who they are.

I totally agree. One point however is related to equal pay for equal work. I agree 100% that people doing the same amount of work should be paid equally. Problem comes in defining what constitutes equal work. Take the example of tennis. Men's and Women's tennis are both equally popular. However, Men's tennis gets more revenue as they are longer. So what would equal pay for equal work mean for tennis. Or say something as simple as a software engineering. How is work defined? Is it hours put in? Lines of code? A lot of service sector jobs where output is not easily measured runs into this issue.

@dhruvrathee All the comments made by famous people who you mentioned to be feminists was in the years 2015, 2016 and 2017.  I understand that you made mention of those famous people's comments after giving you definition of feminism but most people would just gloss over it and thus i have to make view of some of my points.

The definition of feminism has changed over the years by the upcoming generations. The current definition of feminism is to have more rights then men, is if women don't succeed to make it the fault of men, is if men bring out their problems then to imply we don't understand women, is if a wrong deed is pointed out by a man to tag him  as a person who doesn't believe men and women are equal, and a lot more than cannot be listed here. While many of these people you mentioned do believe in feminism they believe in the women having rights to education, opportunities and so on. 

It is true that there was no right to education before to almost all women but that has changed now and women do have the right to education, they even have reservation but let us not talk about that for now. The women who don't have a right to education come from rural households. In most of these households the men are uneducated too. The problem there is the lack of awareness provided by the government among other institutions. But the CURRENT FEMINISTS would blame it on the patriarchy and what not instead of the main concern that is awareness

Almost women these days have opportunities these days equal to men or sometimes more than men. Again the women who do not have opportunities are from rural sectors of the country who are not aware of what opportunities are out there in the country. It is also of the strict traditions of these rural families that have yet to be broken due to the conservative nature of us Indians.

If we speak about crime equality then while there are so many rapes on females taking place around the country there are a negligible number on men as well. NOW by stating this i am not saying i don't understand what women go through or that i condone anything related to women being tormented but men not being tormented. ALL i am stating is that WE are aware of women getting raped but unaware of men getting raped. If a rape case is made/complained to the police station it is a law that the accused man is to be thrown in jail first before any investigation is conducted. And hence women make use of this to frame men for rape, assault and various other crimes. AGAIN, i am not stating that these crimes do not happen i am stating that the severity of these crimes are being taken advantage of by some women and being used against men.

ALL in all, my point being that the definition of feminism has changed over the years by the general public. The video was basically of the past of feminism but not of the current feminism. Kindly bring into the light all of the current feminism issues and problems.

I appreciate your insights on feminism and equal rights in your video. While advocating for equal rights is crucial, it's equally important to address how feminism can be misused to pressure women into conforming to stereotypical male traits, which has created another type of social conformity problem.

Your video emphasizes the need for equal rights, and you have highlighted some examples of misconception about feminism but it overlooks the risk of misuse that can encourage women to emulate male characteristics, including those that are detrimental not only to women but those are detrimental even to men for men having them in the first place - such as irrational aggression and exerting irrational dominance â€“ damaging the natural dynamics between genders. This is just one of the causes of the increased divorce rate; both genders are gradually becoming unwilling to marry, leading to an increase in loneliness. David Deida's 'The Way of the Superior Man' supports this perspective, emphasizing the unique energies of both genders and the disruption caused by losing core energy.

The video should also explore how feminism has become a tool to manipulate women, devaluing activities associated with femininity. This bias, perpetuated by societal pressure, not only affects women but also reinforces the notion that only certain paths, like pursuing a career, hold value. The examples of women being astronauts, scientists, etc., are more highlighted, traditionally male-dominated roles. However, a woman who may willingly want to stay at home or pursue feminine activities feels the pressure of this new social conformity to pursue such male-dominated career paths; only then would she be considered a part of this new phenomenon. This coerced conformity can result in dissatisfaction and a loss of authenticity as individuals pursue paths incongruent with their true desires.

In conclusion, while advocating for equal rights, I request that you make a video addressing the inadvertent consequences of misusing feminism. Promoting a nuanced understanding can create a society that embraces the diversity of choices available to both men and women

To be fair to history, the feminist movement seems to have misappropriated or have been forced to use the word "FEMIN-ism" as a name for the obvious natural right to equality of all genders and sexes. If it was called egalitarianism or simply "equalism" instead of femin-ism, it would not get so badly misunderstood, misused and decried by the patriarchy.
When feminism means equalism, why not use the correct word, i.e. equalism?
This pre-emptive move to cover everything under the name "feminism" probably has (I am guessing here) an interesting set of historical anecdotes or events, in order to protect or optimise the feldgling women's rights and women's liberation movements. But the lasting damage done by this misnomenclature is that feminism finds it hard to break into patriarchal mindsets merely due to the name. The name has become a burden, not an advantage.
As a software developer, I can say with a lot of experience, name your variables, functions and classes correctly, lest some other programmer make a mess of the system by using your code wrongly due to the wrong name.
Note that I am not commenting about anything else than the unfortunate or opportunistic mistake in nomenclature.
Everything else is fine. Baki sab theek hai, sahi hai.
Just to be clear, we must acknowledge the fact that female cats, dogs and rats don't have to listen to the orders of male cats, dogs and rats. Nature has a lot of equality of rights and also a lot of inherent freedoms, which human society denies to both men and women. Some for good reasons, but many for the wrong reasons (vested interests of a sub group).

Dhruv, I've been following you for the past 3-4 yrs, BUT, here, I disagree with you on some points related to patriarchy. 
You say men too should express their emotions (especially, crying) openly. But, no. If there's no shame for a man to cry openly, then do you think that will lead to strong men that the society needs? If a man who has got a whole family looking upon him cries, then how would the family stay emotionally strong? Just imagine, if a kid is seeing his father crying every other day, what strength will he impart in himself? In fact, I'd say women too should not become so emotionally expressive. ... 

Do you think a man (no doubt, physically tougher than a woman) is naturally destined to stay at home and lay on her wife's money? Does this fit the definition of a 'man'? 

I'm not completely in favour of patriarchy. There are bad things in it too. But, what i'm seeing is that in search of a balance, all these 'feminists' are in turn making men weak and too lenient which should not be the case. There should always be a bit of toughness in being a man and that's what leads to strong men and strong societies. All through the history.

The term "aadmi" has its etymological roots in Persian. It is derived from the Persian word "adam" (Ø¢Ø¯Ù…), which means "man" or "human." Over time, this term has been adopted and integrated into various languages, including Urdu and Hindi.

In Islam, both men and women are considered equal in their spiritual worth and accountability before God. They are both regarded as equal partners in worship, responsibility, and reward. However, while Islam promotes equality, it also acknowledges the biological and social differences between men and women, assigning them different roles and responsibilities based on their strengths and abilities. For example:

1. **Spiritual Equality**: Both men and women are equally responsible for fulfilling their religious obligations, such as prayer, fasting, charity, and pilgrimage.

2. **Social Roles**: While men and women have different roles in society, such as caretaking and providing, these roles are complementary rather than superior or inferior. Each gender has its unique strengths and responsibilities.

3. **Modesty and Behavior**: Islam promotes modesty and respectful interaction between men and women. Both are encouraged to lower their gazes and behave with decorum in their interactions with the opposite gender.

4. **Education and Knowledge**: Islam emphasizes the importance of seeking knowledge for both men and women. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said, "Seeking knowledge is obligatory for every Muslim," thereby emphasizing the importance of education regardless of gender.

5. **Legal Rights**: Islam grants women various legal rights, including the right to inherit, own property, engage in business, and seek divorce under certain circumstances. 

6. **Protection and Respect**: Islam emphasizes the protection and respect of women's rights, including protection from abuse, exploitation, and discrimination. The Quran explicitly condemns any form of violence or injustice against women.

Overall, Islam teaches that men and women are partners in their journey of faith and life, each contributing to the betterment of society and the fulfillment of God's will in their unique capacities.

I believe it's crucial to acknowledge and appreciate the inherent differences between men and women. While it's true that both genders possess unique strengths, it's essential to recognize that these strengths often manifest differently. Men tend to excel in areas requiring physical strength and endurance, which historically led to their dominance in tasks like construction and agriculture, and every other field that requires more physical presence, just look around and think about it when you're walking on the roads made my men and looking at the buildings and eating the food that you're about to put in your mouth

Women possess innate qualities that make them exceptional caregivers and nurturers. Their emotional intelligence and empathy equip them well for roles such as motherhood and caretaking. These differences aren't indicative of superiority or inferiority but rather complementarity.

The notion of patriarchy, often misunderstood, reflects not a system of oppression but rather an acknowledgment of historical roles and contributions. Regarding decision-making and emotional management, there is indeed differences in approach between men and women. Men often prioritize logic and rationality in decision-making, while women considers emotional factors more prominently. Men and women have traditionally played distinct but equally valuable roles in society, contributing to its functioning in different ways

In modern society, there's a growing trend towards open-mindedness and inclusivity, which is commendable. However, this openness should not come at the expense of disregarding biological and psychological realities. Embracing diversity of thought and perspective while respecting biological differences is key to fostering a balanced and harmonious society.

I just want to live life the way my parents or grandparents lived. In their time, men were taking responsibility of external affairs and women took responsibility of home and kid's affairs. Both men and women had their sufferings. Neither man nor the woman had very comfortable life then. However, their mind and bodies are conditioned through ages of evolution as well as coaching by elders. Except for some injustices towards women, and sometimes men, it was bit easier for both of them as responsibilities were clearly outlined. Most jobs were only to be taken by men, and these men could marry women to take care of them and share the prosperity from the earnings.

But feminism produces a confusion as to who is responsible for the external affairs of earning and internal affairs of managing home and raising kids. Jobs are already reducing due to automation and machines, besides closure of many govt posts. And with girls taking the few jobs, it becomes difficult for men to get jobs. Now with women settling for less pay, or securing a job by unleashing her sensuality on a male hiring manager, it becomes easier for women to procure a job. Men are forced to join a less paying job or become a shopkeeper. Do you really assume that girl who gets a high paying job settles for any guy of a lower salary or work? How many woman want to continue their job until retirement of age 60? Some may normalize it but reality is way different.

How many times do you notice a woman proposing a man? It's always a man's risk to be mocked for his inadequacies. The fact is even the feminist woman actually believes in patriarchy only.

I support the abolition of sati, right for women's education and suffrage, women's right to choose her partner, etc.. but beyond these I don't see much of a purpose in reservation for women in jobs, legislative seats, and engineering college seats, etc.. If you got talent grab these on merit only. 

There are countless videos on social media where western women are sharing their pain on how they are frustrated carrying the feminist flag and fighting men. I certainly do not want that to happen with my people.

You didn't even called out what bullshit feminists throw at men when men express their problems. Patriarchy theory only looks at sexism from a female standpoint and I find that most feminists are 90% unaware of the different kinds of sexism against men or even claim that there is no such thing as sexism against men because men are privileged (talk about circular reasoning).
There is also the notion that sexism against men is only a side effect of patriarchy against women. This again conveys the female-centric view of feminism, because you could just as well say that sexism against women is just a side effect from sexism against men and that would be just as valid.
What we have is a society full of sexism that strikes both ways. Most sexist norms affect both men and women but in completely different ways. Why would we call such a society a "patriarchy" ?
 Biological differences led to different expectations for men and women, and these expectations have over time not only been cemented but also fleshed out into more and more norms, based on the consequences of the first norms. Many thousands of years later it has become quite the monster with a life of its own, dictating what is expected of men and women today. Again, why would you call this patriarchy or matriarchy instead of just plain "sexism"?
If you concede that men having positions of power is not the source of sexism, then why name your sexism-related worldview after that fact? It is then just another aspect of sexism like any other, or even a natural result of the fact that men are biologically geared for more risky behavior. For example,  the vast majority of homeless people are men. Why is this not a problem to anyone (answer: male disposability)? Why is feminism only focusing on one half of the equation and conveniently forgetting the other half. Men exist in abundance in the top and the bottom of society. Why? 
So to sum it up. Patriarchy is a terrible name for sexism since sexism affects both genders and is not born of male power. Male power is a tiny part of the entirety of sexism and hardly worth naming it after.

That's patriarchy. I am also kind of baffled that you think the solution to mens problems is feminism. Because feminism has such a good track record for solving mens issues right? The fact is that feminism is a major force fighting against mens rights. Both politically, in terms of promotion of new laws and such (promise of marriage is rape, marital rape which is again not gender neutral etc.), this proves that they just want to extort men and treat them as ATM's, and socially, in the way feminists spew hatred upon the mens rights movement and take any chance to disrupt it. As well as the fact that a vast majority of the feminists I've met (and I've met many, both irl and online) have a firm belief that there is no such thing as sexism against men!
You seriously want us to go to these people for help with our issues?

I'm stopping the video at 9:40 because I'm not interested in watching the rest. Personally, I support the idea of proper rights rather than absolute equality. It's amusing to me that both men and women advocate for equal rights. From my perspective, women hold a superior position to men, so naturally, I prefer they don't enter fields like politics or other jobs where they may face unwanted attention from men. My priority is ensuring the safety of my mother, sister, wife, and daughter, protecting them from any harm. However, the push for equal rights has, in my opinion, led to negative consequences.

The feminism prevalent in our society today is concerning because some men exploit it to fulfill their perverse desires. Unfortunately, many women fail to recognize this due to the modern feminist movement advocating for equal rights. In the guise of equality, women often find themselves disrespected and marginalized in various aspects of society. On the other hand, some men take advantage of my viewpoint, denying women the respect and care they deserve. This highlights the dark side of patriarchy, where women are subjected to unnecessary violence instead of being treated with love and affection.

In summary, I believe women should be highly respected individuals in society, but I also wish to shield them from the darker aspects of society.

Here are the differences between men and women. Fun facts
â€¢	Men's skin is about 25% thicker than women's due to higher collagen density.
â€¢	Women need more iron than men from age 14 to 51.
â€¢	Men have more muscle mass and faster, more powerful muscles, while women's muscles resist fatigue better and recover faster.
â€¢	Most men have longer ring fingers than index fingers, while most women have longer index fingers.
â€¢	Folate is crucial for women of childbearing age for fetal neural development.
â€¢	Men have more gray matter, and women have more white matter and larger memory centers in their brains.
â€¢	Women's circadian rhythms are often shorter than 24 hours, while men tend to be night owls; women cope better with sleep deprivation.
â€¢	Women use fat as primary fuel during exercise, men use carbohydrates.
â€¢	Men have higher testosterone levels, which decline about 1% yearly after age 30; women's estrogen levels drop after menopause.
â€¢	Both sexes reach peak bone mass around age 30, but women lose bone faster after menopause and need more calcium.
â€¢	Men require more calories due to higher muscle mass, stature, and metabolic rate.
â€¢	Women have about 10% more body fat, which supports reproductive physiology.
â€¢	Women's body fat is typically in the hips and thighs, while men's is around the stomach.
â€¢	Men generally need higher-protein diets.
â€¢	Men have lower resting heart rates but higher peak heart rates than women.
â€¢	Men have more red blood cells and generally higher blood pressure than women.
â€¢	Both sexes have similar vitamin D needs, but older women need more for calcium absorption.
â€¢	Men are less likely to seek regular medical checkups and may not be as forthcoming about symptoms.
â€¢	Zinc needs are similar for both sexes, but pregnant and post-menopausal women need more; men store zinc in their prostate.
â€¢	Men are less sensitive to cold temperatures.
â€¢	Women have better senses of smell and taste, with more olfactory neurons and taste buds.
â€¢	Men are more likely to be colorblind but sense movement better; women distinguish colours more finely.

The crux of the matter lies in the harsh realities we face today. While legal frameworks advocate for gender equality, the prevailing issue is the societal acceptance of this principle. Take, for instance, the disparity seen in dating app culture, where a significant portion of women match with a select few men, perpetuating skewed dynamics. Documentaries like "Indian Sons in Jail" shed light on the misuse of laws that seemingly favor women, leading to a troubling notion of "women always being right."

This imbalance extends to legal matters, where many men find themselves disadvantaged, especially in cases of infidelity where alimony demands can still be made. The current legal landscape seems to place an undue burden of trust solely upon men, leaving them vulnerable in a society increasingly driven by self-interest.

While some women may adhere to fairness, the systemic bias remains a stark reality for many men, leaving them with little recourse. The shift from a perspective of all men being right to one where all women are perceived as such isn't progressâ€”it's a distortion of justice.

Moreover, these laws often fail where they're needed most, as many cases go unreported, exacerbating mental health issues and even costing lives. The elites, untouched by such laws, further complicate the lives of the middle class, while influencers like Dhruv Rathee seemingly overlook these critical issues.

India's constitutional ethos of ensuring innocence prevails, even if guilty escape, falters in addressing the gender imbalance plaguing society. The erosion of family values and mental well-being underscores the urgent need for legal reforms that truly address societal needs.

The issues extend beyond gender dynamics, impacting population decline, job scarcity, and relationship dynamics. It's imperative to reassess the efficacy of current feminist ideologies and prioritize solutions that benefit all, not just a select few.

In a country like India, grappling with multifaceted challenges, it's essential to address these issues comprehensively and embark on meaningful dialogue and action for a more equitable future.

In the "free world," all genders should have the freedom to pursue their desires in areas such as education, politics, and work. However, in the name of feminism, women today often feel pressured to excel academically and professionally, which can be disheartening. Feminism should offer girls choices and freedom rather than imposing obligations on them. It's essential to recognize that societal changes take time; the progress achieved in education and career opportunities over the past 50-100 years cannot instantly override thousands of years of societal evolution.

While I completely understand and believe Women should get equal rights.... Every community has its own restrictions and law for women and modern day world would deny the fact that these restrictions and laws were created or introduced to maintain a balance between Humans in many areas in aspect of life. 

Yes, women can work, they can learn, they can educate themselves, they are free to go anywhere but the catch is if both Men and Women work who would look after their family? Who would take of their children? Who would look after their parents? 

Women are way stronger than man in many ways but men would still be superior. I not against the equality we are talking here about. I am only trying make my a point that Men and Women co-exist its cycle of life, Nature and system created by Earth or its people to maintain a certain balance, peace, harmony and love to this planet that we men are destroying. 

Women is stronger as they have a ability to empower herself and her family. Women can give anyone hope, Women can rectify or undo mistakes (I don't mean women pay for men's mistakes) men would do. While I generally agree with you most of the time, it's important to note that just because some famous people support feminism doesn't necessarily mean their IQ level is higher than ours. Being famous doesn't guarantee correctness, and I don't believe females should be denied the right to work.

Point 1: If a girl is saying we should have cerebral opportunities, I agree they should. However, claiming complete equality in capabilities between genders is not naturally and scientifically accurate. Women may not perform physically demanding work as men do, and they may not develop the same level of muscularity.

Point 2: Feminists advocating for equality are not expressing rocket science. They are simply stating that men and women should be complete equally. but not Ready to work rough work they should not use "complete" they should use the correct word "cerebral" opportunities.

Point 3: *If all girls are equal, they should not limit themselves to working only in comfortable environments* like air-conditioned spaces. Equality should extend to all fields, including labor-intensive jobs such as agriculture, construction, the military, mining, welding, plumbing, and mechanics and more... if they are not equal, we are agreeing they should work in comfortable environments. if they are forcing, we are complete equal they should agree to work in where difficult or muscular work have, we are not for that. then it's call Doglapan and for that we do not agree and ready.

I'll tell you my take on this :-
Absolutely, all men and women are equal. And yes, i do believe that women should get equal rights, equal highest possible education, equal opportunities and equal pay as that of men.
BUT, i want to clarify the category of women that should be eligible to get this. Only those women, who are not married, or do not have a responsibility of the family, should pursue for their career. If a married women does a 9 to 5 job, who will take care of the kids? And who will look after the household work after all the tiredness of a 8 to 10 hour job? The work in a house is just as important as the work outside. Yes, it's a shame that women do not get enough credit and pay for managing the house, and we should talk on this matter, but this work is important for a family. And if you say that women can manage both, ask every women that if they get to choose only one, will they choose? The answer will be a yes.
A few years ago i heard a news from Bangalore that a women threw her handicapped son from her building because he was crying and distracting her from her job. No sane person would do this, and to stop this, the society has built some rules that applies to both men and women. I am not patriarchal, i am a feminist. Just not a irrational pseudo-feminist.

I don't have time to find fancy English words like "normative conformity", "fallacy", "matriarchy" blah blah blah to support my argument. But I hope if you understand simple Hindi and you have slightly higher sense than common sense, then you will understand what I am trying to say, so hear me out - 

Apko cool dikhne keliye hamesha society ke weaker side to hi support krna jaruri nahi hai. Agar saare aadmi mante hai ki aurat ko apne pati ko parmeshwar saman manna chaiye to kuch "rational" as you say and sensible mard bhi hote hai jo apni auratko devi ka roop mante hai. So instead saari ladies to ye sikhaya jaye ki patiko parmeshwar na mano kyu na ham saare aadmiyo ko sikhaye ki aap jitna parmeshwar hai utnahi appki aurat devi saman hai. Par nahi aap ko to jobhi cultural, traditional lagta hai aap fataak se usko logical angle deke logoko bahar ghasitne lagte ho. Aur rahi baat equal rights ki to haan aurato ko past mai bohot bhedbhav sehna pada hai but iska ye matlab nhi ki aurat har kaammai mard ki barabari kr sakti hai ya viceversa. Naturally/biologically mard stronger hote hai so physically harder tasks wo krte aa rahe hai aur aurat baki tasks jisme wo acchi hai wo krti aa rahi hai. Isko hamari bhasha mai efficiently ghar chalana kehte hai. Isme aapne pure aadmi prajatiko hi Villain ghoshit kr diyağŸ˜‚Haan aaj ye sab baatein point nhi banati, (as aaj major kaam aurate equally better way mai kr sakti hai) but aajbhi agar hum jhagadne lage ki physically harder tasks like military, construction works mai auratoko equal rights de toh economically hamara desh collapse kr jayega. (App hi ne ekbaar apne video mai kaha tha - "Ki jab ekbar desh ki prime minister ek aurat bani thi toh hume bhi pata hai kya hua tha") Ye mai nahi bolra ye aapne bola tha. 
Rahi baat ghar ke kaamo ki(kyoki aapko to utne tak hi samaj aata hai) to jo nahi kamata wo gharke kaam kre agar dono kamatae hai to dono milke kare.

Rahi baat office mai equal pay ki, toh mere college mai iss saal saari ladkiya place ho chuki hai badi badi MNCs mai (jo hame hi pata hai ki most of them kaam krneke bajay companiyoka kaam badhayengi) aur college ke some of the best coders unplaced baithe hai. Kaise? "Womens quota", "Equal rights" "Diversity hiring" Tadaaaaa!!!! Aur agar koi aurat sachmai apne kaam mai aadmiyo se acchi hai to usko equal nahi aadmiyose jyada pay kro ye mai bhi maanta hun. 
Basically, aadmiyo ko sudharo naki Aurato ko pura western cultural mindset deke desh ka innocence mat khatam karo.

The video seems impressive at first glance, and it's nice to hear, but it's quite detached from reality. The idea of equality sounds wonderful until you hit a moment of realization that you've been duped, and there will come a time when you'll find yourself reflecting on it with tears. If simply listening to this person brings you comfort and makes you smile, it's time to step back and question it. That comfort zone is a slippery slope into a world of delusions, distancing you further from the truth. You unwittingly become the ideal target for marketers, transforming into the very product they sell.

Every time you encounter new information, if you just paused to critically analyze it, to sift through it with your own intellect, to research and ponder deeply from various perspectives, you'd shield yourself from the corporate world's hypnotic grasp. If reading this irks you or gets under your skin, it's a sign that the corporate spell has begun its work on you, and you've become ensnared. But once the veil is lifted and you see the reality for what it is, there's no turning back. Stay alert and watch out for these snares.

Itâ€™s not about "Equal Right". Rather it should have been "Appropriate Rights". 

For example: Suppose only one chair available in a waiting lounge and 3 people are demanding the chair. One of them is lame & the other two are fit & fine. Now who is more eligible for sitting in it?

Equal Right: Everyone has equal right to sit there.

Appropriate Right: The lame should be given the chair.

By the way, to the so called faminists, if it is appropiate to have paid maternal leave, what wrong the father did. He also should have paternal leave, no matter the company gets busted. After all equal rights matters.

At the risk of being called a "misogynist" here's my two cents as a socially conservative guy:
There are many people who don't oppose equal rights but oppose the way feminism manifests in society.
Everyone talks about misogyny and it is called out which is a good thing but misandry is heavily downplayed.
And many women resort to both feminist and patriarchal ideas depending on whichever suits them at the specific situation.
Many immoral and toxic behaviors are often promoted in the name of feminism using the argument of "it's her choice".
If you feminists really think that your ideology is good then in that case your marketing is terrible.
And by the way I'm not a misogynist. I also think so-called alpha males and incels are cringe.
I respect women who respect men and society as a whole as well as their own bodies. It's as simple as that.

It is true that feminism started with the purpose of equal rights, but recent incidents are proves that feminism has taken a wrong direction now and it should be scrapped and some other movement like equalinism (or something) should be started. Cases where women harass men with the same rights provided through feminism are increasing and men don't have any rights to defend themselves, more wives are cheating upon their husbands. There are scams going on in the market with the help of women. 
Additionally, the job market is suffering because of international reasons, the pressure of income is upon the males in the society (even most of the women pressuries males), with the growing population the competition increases, at the same time various jobs have got cast based reservations, on top of these now even women have started competiting, so it has become very hard for the males to atleast land a job. (My personal experience in my college on-campus placements is that companies prefer an unskilled woman upon a skilled man). 
Moreover indian constitution has always tried to not discriminate among any of the groups, so there is no need of any movement to get rights (rights are there already). It's the social stigma that needs to be addressed and that can be done through awareness campaigns.
Personally I don't support any movement, I think nothing is permanant and hence nothing should be made into a necessity. Infact the people who have qualities should be given the chances, and it should not be taken as a pride that there are more male workers / female workers / trans workers. I wonder when will people start treating work as work and not associate it with status, gender, caste, etc.

The points you make are about 1st and 2nd generation feminism, but the 3rd and 4th generation feminism captures opposing views to the 1st and 2nd - especially with the addition of trans, which pollute the definition in its original form.

While your video addresses the 1st and 2nd generation points, it fails to express its distinction on the 3rd and 4th generation meaning of the term. Which can in turn could mislead. I would presume that this topic isn't covered in its entirety or was made in a hurry with clickbait terms. 

The definition of terms in language evolve over time and unfortunately language cannot sufficiently capture the evolving nature of them.

One thing to add: while we all cry foul about â€œrightsâ€, the â€œresponsibilityâ€ aspect is often overlooked - and along with Bollywood-inspired toxic feminism, this is another reason for misinterpretation of feminism. For instance - many women do jobs and earn money, but very few (at least in India) put themselves as primary (or equal) responsible person for familyâ€™s financial security. Thats still the â€˜mans jobâ€™.

As long as one interprets feminism as means to be equal/ equivalent in both responsibility and rights - and not as some fancy buzzword to exploit men, or squeeze out the best of both worlds - you understand it was never about just men or women, itâ€™s purely â€œhumaneâ€, and honestly, thereâ€™s no other way.

At the end, nature didnâ€™t create us to compete against each other - but to complement.

Patriarchy: System of governance ran by men with more power & responsibility entrusted to men especially the ruling elites.
Feminism: Political ideology or movement centred around the female.
Masculism/Masculinism: Political ideology or movement centred around the male, in other words male version of feminism.
Matriarchy: System of governance ran by women with more power & responsibility entrusted to women especially the ruling elites, in other words female version of patriarchy.
Egalitarian: Being a supporter of Egalitarianism i.e. the idea of treating everyone with equality.

I can't thankyou enough for this particular video Dhruv. I'm a first year political science student, who faced so much criticism the moment i said I'm a feminist among my new classmates which ofcourse wasn't surprising but pretty disappointing. But that didn't stop me from giving them reasons and indulging into arguments as to why it's not a 'CANCER' (that's what they claim it is) i thought i might change their perspective for good But the saddest moment in this was, when a girl mocked me infront of those people as to 'why do i need Feminism? Don't we have equal rights, given to us by the constitution?' And i saw them giving that smug smile to show how I am the only crazy one here. 

In that moment i really wanted to ask her, "We abolished Untouchability under Article 17 no? Then why we still see it being practiced widely across the country?" 

But alas! I felt defeated in that moment because it was coming from a girl of my same age.

P.S. I'm gonna share this video in my class group and i dont care if they think I'm batshit crazy. ( for you gave me the courage that I've lost in bw.)

I will not support you 100%, Dhruve. Males and females are not the same 100%. God created them for different work. In some work women are perfect, their men are not perfect and vice versa. People, by the name of feminism, give all the men's work to the women, and what do you gain now in this generation? More than half the percentage of divorce. Nobody wants to compromise for each other because now everyone thinks they don't need anyone since they earn money. In the middle, their kids suffer and get spoiled. The husband is a protector of the woman, but whoever tortured their wife, there should be rules and legal ways to deal with that, and the same goes for others. You never can expect when you walk with your wife, and some men are harassing her. At that time, of course, she will say you are the man; you should protect me. But men never can expect that. Of course, there is a purpose to create them differently physically and mentally.

This is why old-time family lives together. Of course, there were issues and suffering, but at least they learned to live together in the end. Somebody has the right over you in some cases; it doesn't mean that women have fewer rights. When we were kids or teens, our parents had power over us; they loved us, punished us, and disciplined us. Does it mean they were wrong? Parents and kids should have the same right to live together? Now western countries have this kind of mentality and make this rule. If their parents shout at them and even a little bit punish them, then they call the police. In this way, the young generation gets spoiled, and families get broken.

You also said the similarity between men and women. I know both of us have ears, nose, hands, and so on. But animals have that as well; similarity. Does it mean we and animals can do the same work? The main difference between humans and animals is we are intellectual. We use more brains than animals. This makes everything different and works differently. Women and men don't have the same feelings, brains, and hearts. Yes, it looks the same physically, but the way it thinks and feels is different. And that makes us different to do different work, where women are better in some cases, and males are better in other cases. We have even different choices of colors and toys from childhood. This is natural. We are making it unnatural.

Saying this, you are actually breaking society. Just remove the oppression part. Nobody should oppress each other. There is some extraordinary passion of women as well, and they can be astronauts, doctors, etc. And they still can do that. They did that before and are doing it now as well. God sets a rule as he creates humans, and he knows better how we get along. Problems happen when we each have different opinions and try to make our own rules. Just accept nature as it shows us. Women look lovely maintaining kids, houses, and families, and respect them and protect them as your wives. In the same way, men are physically stronger than women; they are good in outside work. Let them work for you. It looks sound and balanced. Just don't oppress each other. That's it.

Enough of what ideal feminism is and how it will benefit both men and women, let's talk about what goes on in real world. Feminism and female empowerment are widely used, especially in India to justify wrongs done by women on men. "Women have suffered for so long, men's turn now" is a common feeling among so many Indian feminist, including men. To say that not a single feminist agreed with Neha Dhupia there is a big overstatement. There were many. There are also many who justify similar scenarios. Low paying and physically challenging jobs are never scrutinised for being male dominated, only cozy and comfy high paying office jobs have the gaze of so called feminists set on them. Ask the feminist if she'd prefer being deployed as a front line combatant at the LOC while her partner stays back at home praying for her well being. It just doesn't happen as it's not natural. Ask the feminist if he/she supports gender quotas in job market. Most would say yes and that goes directly against the feel good idea of equality. Saying women don't have a body as strong as men but have a mind that can compete with men's so they should only be expected to demand equality in office jobs is also not fair. Why should 50% men who could've potentially grabbed a high paying office job be rejected to pave way for women with similar intellectual calibre or sometimes even less just for the sake of "numerical equality"? That's goddamn inequality. 
And btw it's not like I wish for women to start lifting guns at the LOC or start laying bricks from tomorrow. That'd be a nightmare.

Actually.. use of word (feminism)is going wrong , Now the society is moving towards Matriarchy..

The video discusses the concept of feminism and patriarchy, aiming to dispel misconceptions and provide clarity on their definitions and implications in society.
Feminism is defined as advocating for political, economic, and social equality between men and women, not seeking superiority for either gender.
Patriarchy, on the other hand, refers to a social system where men hold control and power over women.
Examples are provided to illustrate how patriarchal ideologies impact both men and women negatively, perpetuating harmful norms and expectations.
The video highlights that feminism does not seek to pit men against women but challenges patriarchal structures that harm both genders.
It addresses the issue of toxic masculinity, which pressures men to conform to rigid gender roles and suppress emotions.
The video criticizes the portrayal of superficial feminism in media and calls attention to genuine feminist films and movements that advocate for equality and challenge patriarchal norms.
Instances of hypocrisy in society's treatment of gender issues are highlighted, including double standards in relationships and societal expectations.
The video emphasizes the importance of understanding and supporting genuine feminist movements that strive for equality and freedom for all genders.
Ultimately, it calls for the dismantling of patriarchal structures and the promotion of genuine equality and opportunities for all individuals, irrespective of gender.

*What is Islam?* 
Islam is the name of the religion, or more properly the â€˜way of lifeâ€™, which God (Allah) has revealed and which was practiced by all of the Prophets and Messengers of God that He sent to mankind.  Islam specifically means being in the state of submission to God, worshipping Him Alone, and reverently accepting and obeying His Law. 

*Who are Muslims?*
The Arabic word â€œMuslimâ€ literally means â€œsomeone who is in a state of Islam (submission to the will and law of God)â€.  The message of Islam is meant for the entire world, and anyone who accepts this message becomes a Muslim.

*Who is Allah?*
Often one hears the Arabic word â€œAllahâ€ being used in discussions regarding Islam.  The word â€œAllahâ€ is simply the Arabic word for Almighty God, and is the same word used by Arabic speaking Christians and Jews.  As a matter of fact, the word Allah was in use far before the word God ever came into existence, since English is a relatively new language.  If one were to pick up an Arabic translation of the Bible, one would see the word â€œAllahâ€ being use where the word â€œGodâ€ is used in English.  For instance, Arabic speaking Christians say that Jesus is, according to their canon belief, the Son of Allah.  In addition, the Arabic word for Almighty God, â€œAllahâ€, is quite similar to the word for God in other Semitic languages. 

*Who is Muhammad?*
The last and final prophet whom God sent to humanity was the Prophet Muhammad, may the mercy and blessings of God be upon him.

*What are the Teachings of Islam?*
The foundation of the Islamic faith is belief in absolute Monotheism (the Oneness of God).  This means to believe that there is only one Creator and Sustainer of everything in the Universe, and that nothing is divine or worthy of being worshipped except for Him.

*What is the Quran?*
The Quran is the final revelation of Allah to all of mankind, which was spoken by Allah the Exalted Himself and conveyed through the Arch-Angel Gabriel in Arabic to the Prophet Muhammad, in sound, word and meaning.

*What does Islam say about Jesus?*

The Islamic belief about Jesus demystifies for us who the real Jesus was.Â Jesus in Islam was an extraordinary individual, chosen by God as a Prophet and sent to the Jewish people.Â He never preached that he himself was God or the actual son of God.Â He was miraculously born without a father, and he performed many amazing miracles such as healing the blind and the lepers and raising the dead â€“ all by Godâ€™s permission.Â Muslims believe that Jesus will return before the day of Judgement to bring justice and peace to the world.Â This Islamic belief about Jesus is similar to the belief of some of the early Christians.

I rarely comment on any videos but I really want to thankyou for this video. 
When someone asks me to explain feminism or to justify my emotions against their patriarchal behaviour, it makes me feel so angry and helpless to be honest. How can something which is so logical and simple be so difficult to understand. The reason is simple- people who talk about fake feminism more than feminism were sexist from the very beginning. 
So yes, sometimes I try to explain, sometimes it's too hard so I get angry instead, and sometimes I just tell them that you are wrong and should read up on it because I am not going to spoonfeed you the information.
So ladies, I know it takes a toll on you..but let's go deeper in it..feel worse about the society but also stay positive within because change is happening and changes will happen for the good. 
There are feminists, men, who don't feel insecure everysingle time someone talks about feminism, who don't feel attacked, women who don't feel like they are betraying their better halves while talking about this. 
Once I was explaing about women rights to one of my friends and she tells me after listening to everything that yes all of that is fine but you can't hate on boys and should speak about them as well. And I was so surprised because I genuinely thought that she was getting me. I reminded her that literally nothing I had said had ANYTHING going against men particularly. It's the society. If that society comprises of those men (sexist) too then why should we be shy to speak up against them? Secondly there is absolutely nothing wrong in talking about men suffering from the patriarchal society, because they do..a lot! But saying ' talking about their sufferings' in response to women's suffering is just kind of comparing the two and taking no responsibility and sort of saying shut up and stop whining. Why can't we talk about both.
 Feminism also doesn't mean that if I have 10 mins to say something, I give five to women and 5 to men. That is so stupid! Somedays I can talk entirely about men and somedays entirely about women and that doesn't make anyone a lesser person. i can talk about women's rights for hours and it's FINE. it's needed. We are all in the same boat. Men are suffering without them realising that they are suffering. 
And being a women, explaining the most basic of the things..I can only imagine how many more years it will take for things to even come anywhere closer. 
So ladies please start getting offended and asking the right questions xD

*Please do a PODCAST with Andrew Tate*

Equality is always dangerous. We should strive for Equanimity/Justice. 
To all these Alpha males and Animal movie lovers - I have just 1 point. 
Imagine the movie with Ranbir Kapoor as the son of a labourer in a real world.....all your Alphas and gammas will disappear.

If you give the same normal printed books to student with normal vision and a blind student for their exams...it is equality but not justice.

We should be careful about feminism as to how its understood now. Feminism wants to bring Equality. It says that women should have "same" rights as men.
So if Men play 5-setter tennis matches and women play 3-setter tennis matches for the entire tournament, then how can we have equal Pay to both??
If Men in military do the heavy lifting which obviously women cannot then how can there be equal pay??
In another situation a female and male CEO should have SAME Pay as the work effort is same for both.

Vice-versa - If women take 6 months maternity leave, then should Men also take 6 months leave? No....right, because there is no justice there.

We want to force everyone to have 1 spouse, and make prostitution illegal for all - Equality. So what will happen to a 28 year old person whose spouse is long-term sick or becomes physically incapable in satisfying their partner. Also if this person is not capable of living alone...then what will happen to them??

We can take this concept further - If entry fee for good Medical colleges is 50 lac rupees for all then there is equality but how will a equally talented child of a rickshaw driver ever dream to become a doctor?? There should not be reservations but apply different fee structures based on economic background.

If we all think about JUSTICE rather than EQUALITY or FEMINISM all our world problems will be solved.

Now that I think about it....the last time my best friend cried was in our childhood...he cried because he did not get admission to his desired school with a very good score, but his friend got admitted even when he had 30 points lower than my friend because he was SC/ST category. I consoled him that day. But since we have grown up, I've never seen him cry again. And I know the reason why....his friends off course!! It's a matter of shame in their friends circle if you cry.

Another incident of my school:- I was passing by a group of senior boys in the playground who were practising shotput. When a boy threw a shot, another boy commented, "Kya bhai ladkiyon jaisa fenk rha hai!" Which made that boy embarrassed....
That comment offended that boy & me at the same time. I felt like I wish I hadn't listened because now that comment will forever stay in my mind rent-free.
Such things definitely should be the reason for "Smash Patriarchy".
It does no good to men & women both.

There were many evils in India before independence.  Some of these evils are:

 polygamy

 Purdah system

 tradition of Sati

 Ban on widow remarriage

 no education for girls

 female foeticide

 child marriage

 Caste System

 Ban on women's education and widow remarriage

 Disrespectful behavior towards widows

 communalism

 dowry system

 To remove these evils, social reformers launched movements from time to time.  After independence, now these evils are negligible.  However, many evils are still seen in India.



 Many thanks to all those great men and great women who tried to stop these evils.


 We all are lucky that we got the Constitution of India which has provisions to protect the interests of everyone.

Feminism can be good if done right. If not, ya messed up. Badly.

With that being said though, feminism is a movement that started out with good intentions, but its messaging has been so distorted that people are misunderstanding what it actually is, which is, fundamentally, equality of the sexes.

I call it the 'movement of Theseus', akin to the ship of Theseus paradox, basically how much of a well-intentioned movement can be changed, distorted and torn apart until it's no longer what it started out as.

Edit: shows such as Four More Shots aren't feminism. It's buzzwordy, pop feminism that doesn't actually do anything.
