Long text warning!! But please read if you have time, it's just my opinion/observation (No hate):

what you defined in feminism, is perfectly fine in theory.
feminism is all about equal rights for all men & women. I do understand that. and I believe, almost everyone who use internet in a mindful way knows the real meaning of feminism. So, men aren't hating feminism because they don't know what feminism is. It's because there's a difference between theory & practical. 

Let's understand it in this way,
in school/college when we study topics related to physics & stuffs, we are 1st taught the theory behind that topic. In the theory everything is perfect, everything is beautiful, everything just works flawlessly because there's not many complications (we assume/neglect lots of things for simplicity's sake). 
But then we are sent to perform the same thing in a practical lab, then we observe that whatever we've learnt in theory is not completely matching with how things work in reality. Because reality doesn't work with our assumptions/we can't just neglect any parameter as our wish. With that we always come to the conclusion that, it's ok to assume things in theory for simplicities sake but you can't just neglect the randomness of reality, because reality is what matters the most.

Now, where am I going with this one? Well, the definition of feminism/the massage that it portrays is great as long as you're just saying it, like in theory.
But, do we really see the practical implementation of feminism in our society? Do we really see people use feminism with gender neutrality? NO!!!!
Whenever women do something stupid, majority of the time(what I've observed), then they start playing the "w" card in the name of feminism, that they have all right to do anything/wear anything/it's her choice/none can give her even an advice(not even father or husband), because they say men are controlling them & they are free/will do anything they want. Why? Because they are true feminists(they say). They believe in women empowerment & all. I have never seen any guy do unethical things in the name of feminism, if fact men don't even use feminism even when they themself are suffering. 

I'm not talking about those movies that you've mentioned. It's happening in real life. And this number is a lot, A LOT!!!!!! And increasing!
If in practical/reality these feminists believe so much in equality, then where were they when women were charging men for false rape cases & the men went to jail. And after a long time, the rape case was proved false, and the man's life/career is destroyed. But still, nothing happened to the women. Why no feminist talked/even cared about it. Even I've read comments of girls saying, "whatever happened it was perfect, men need to suffer, because men also rapes women" (that's their logic)!

Where were your feminism, when women were openly abusing/slapping men (even in house)? And the men can't do anything because he knows that if he does something, the public would beat the living hell out of him & those so-called feminists are abusing their "feminist"/"women" card for these reasons. And at the end, nothing happens to the women, people give the man sympathy by saying, "she's a women, what can we do after all.". everyone acts as if it's no big deal. But if the gender were reversed, then it would be a huge HUGE issue. everyone will blame the man so hard & he will go to jail for assaulting. And also, she can file a rape case on him as a bonus!!!

See, pretty easy to describe feminism but reality is much complex. Not saying you should hate feminism. but instead of feminism, we should follow equalism/rights for all souls on earth. I know feminism does the exact same thing. But it is being misused so much in society (specially women abuse it so much) because, feminism has the word, "feminine" in it.
I think we should promote equalism more than anything.

@Dhruv, first of all, thanks for making video on such a complicated topic. Your presentation is mind blowing as always. But I think you have oversimplified some things and I want your opinion on some of the things that you missed.

1) You mentioned that the women who believe in patriarchy do so bcz of normative confomity. That is - they only do so bcz of societal norms. But is it totally true? Isn't patriarchy also very "convenient " for girls? As mentioned in the movie Barbie, due to patriarchy, women don't have to take hard decisions, they don't have to face harsh conditions that men are trained to embrace. Don't you think many women like this? Which brings me to the next point 

2) If we are talking about "equal" rights- sure, I'm up for it. But I want equality in every front. Not just for the powerful or gainful situations. I want equal number of females soldiers fighting equally at the forefronts of wars for all countries. I want equal number of women in hardworking jobs like plumbing, construction work, sewage cleaning, moving and packing services etc. Is everyone up for it? 

3) Why should the very term that speaks about "equality" start with "females"? I understand the historical point of view but since we are trying to change the society, should not we choose a term that sounds more gender neutral?

4) You compared males and females as 75% same in terms of physiological norms. Being a PhD in Molecular Biology, let me tell you that Males and Females are different in terms of chromosome (XY vs XX) that is the very beginning of life. And there are many other differences physiologically such as bone density, muscular structure, hormonal composition etc. that you oversimplified. Men and women are complementary to each other. Although, I think overall your presentation agrees with this concept but still the representation is slightly misleading. 

My overall take is - we should believe in "equity" of rights rather than "equality" of rights. "Equality" is a very oversimplified, vague term that creates confusion. "Equity" refers to giving everyone same opportunities whereas "equality" refers to giving everyone same outcome. They sound similar but are very different. Stay well and keep making good videos.

The Hindu Code Bill refers to a series of laws aimed at reforming Hindu personal law in India. It was a significant legislative effort initiated by the Indian government to bring about social reform and gender equality within Hindu society. The Hindu Code Bill sought to address issues such as marriage, divorce, inheritance, and adoption among Hindus, which were previously governed by traditional customs and religious practices that often discriminated against women.

The bill was primarily championed by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and other social reformers. However, it faced strong opposition from conservative elements within Hindu society. Despite this opposition, the Hindu Code Bill was eventually passed in various iterations between 1955 and 1956, marking a significant step forward in the quest for gender equality and social justice in India.


Dr. B.R. Ambedkar he, was a strong advocate for women's rights. He believed in gender equality and fought against discrimination based on gender. Ambedkar emphasized the importance of education for women and their participation in the workforce. He was instrumental in drafting laws that aimed to improve the status of women in Indian society, including the Hindu Code Bill, which sought to give women equal rights in matters such as marriage, inheritance, and property ownership. Ambedkar's vision for women's rights was rooted in social justice and equality for all members of society.

I have a different opinion on this particular topic.

When we talk about any term implementation in our society we should look the conditions, situations facing societies who are adopting that particular culture.

Men and women both are equal in terms of having rights as a civilian, as a child, as a sibling, as individual human being living in any country. But at the same time when they constitute a family then they become responsible for certain things. Individually they both should have equal rights. But when it comes to form a new family then they both adopt specific designation.

Marriage is a constitution. 

When a man gets married nature demands from him to provide for his wife and child. Why?? I tell you later. But at the same time, when a woman gets married nature demands from her to make home. Be there for her child, be there for home, be there when her husband returns home tired. Be there to cook or provide healthy food via any cook or by her own. Be there to  maintain home, and more precisely for her child. Child demands mother love by nature. 

Do you remember? When we had returned from school in our old school days we always hunted "where is mom? Where she's gone?" Because we too wanted that mother should be there for us.

Women by nature is more into patience when it comes to bear the tantrums of children. Women are good enough in nurturing and upbringing of kids by God. Women are good in managing things precisely and keenly.

Men on the contrary, are good in leading home. They have leadership qualities. They are strong enough in case they lost their jobs, they can work hard physically to earn in any catastrophic conditions. That's why God has given them power and strong head. They could be patient but not more than a women in case of facing child tantrums. They supposingly give children time but not able to sit all day at home to nurture kids and bear their emotions. Men are not made in this way.

This all what I said above is general wordics, I'm not targeting any specific situation. 


Now imagine, how would it look like when both man and woman started doing jobs. I'm talking about average 9 to 5 job. Not above any business thingy, not talking about working hard in sites. Just an average office job or 9 to 5 any job. 

When both father and mother are absent for certain amount of time from home who would take care of child?? Grandma?? Baby sitter?? How long!? Let's suppose you both man and woman are making hell lots of money and somehow able to pay for cook(chef), home cleaner, for cleaning cloths, for baby sitter, bills, schooling of kids and what not. In this regard, you can just run the home, you can say (bachy pall rahy hain, lekin tarbiyt ni ho rahi) children lack mind relief and more into mental illness due to absence of parents counselling role in their lives, and could not get benefits from home making,eventually both will think where they'd put thereselves into. This is very hectic and busy routine.

9 to 5 is very hectic, a woman returns from work and instead of relaxing she have to take care of child what they ate? What they did whole day? What they all have to eat in dinner and at night both partners have to give time to eachother too. Man can cook, can do laundry, can treat kids but not in the manner what a woman can do. 

In america, where feminism movement started everyone now know whats the ground reality is, so they are not interested in marriage constitution any more. A large number of people have directed their minds into bf/gf culture or living in relationships. Where both gets benefits from each others physically but not into having family any more. Woman have to suffer a lot. She has to deal with her own health monthly with good amount of mood swings in addition to having pregnancy and pain during it. While giving birth she has to go through alot, and after that she has to be their for child for a good amount of time till the baby sitter thing.
This all brought them into not having family.

Japan and korea are good example of working of both genders. They're not interested in planning to have a family of their own . Family demands responsibility. And no one have enough time to take responsibilities other than work. They're working because they have to survive, and their sexual needs are already been meet. So what's the point of getting married and having child?? Their women have 0 birthrate expected in 2022. Pathetic.
There are unemployment because if both genders are working then there will be less opportunities for men to be able to run a whole family. That is why it is becoming a need to work both husbands and wives. And eventually time is near when they both will be no more interested in having a family.

So the conclusion is that, working of both genders leads to fall of marriage constitution. So if a man earns and provides for his family he demands respect in a positive manner because he's the one who remains out of the house in any season or condition to be able to provide. And woman should be respected because no matter what she's dealing with she's there for her child and husband to give them a good environment of home and care with love and kindness.

Putting men and women under the same banner of exploitation in a patriarchal society is dangerous. If someone says that the patriarchal system makes living difficult for men too, one must remember that it makes it worse for women. The level of freedom a man enjoys is far more superior than a woman. Moreover, when advocating for equality, one must always remember the biological differences between man and woman. A woman goes through a menstrual cycle every month and this period is extremely exhaustive both physically and mentally. Also a man cannot be pregnant. As such there cannot be equal treatment of men and women. A woman has to be given some concession on this ground. Also due to the fact that women are poorly represented (having less power)  in every aspect of life in a patriarchal society, they have to be given more rights sometimes over men, for instance, some specific laws in IPC which are deliberately made women centric.

Pehle sirf ladkon per pressure tha employment ka... ab ladkiyon per bhi hona chahiye kya, kya yehi equality hai? I'm sure that's not the narrative here from feminism. But that will be the end result. That's because regardless of the gender, education, culture, the world always had a majority of innocent and gullible people falling for a propaganda or some other narrative. Majority people will not learn the definition you provided for feminism. They will have their own interpretations, (perhaps guided by their inner devil or by greater good). That's why you see people talk more about women empowerment rather than men empowerment, you see more and more laws being prepared and passed in favor of women. If one side is making their own interpretations, there's another side taking advantage of this narrative. And the example I provided at the start is only one small case. The world was always a hostile place for humans, and men took the onus, or were told, to safeguard their women. As a counter argument, can you say why didn't were women told to protect men? All these arguments are for sure not part of that narrative, but that's what people will end up with. So, what's the best way out? Well, it's a complex world. Perhaps one lifetime isn't enough to know everything. If you're like Dhruv, you're in a better position to learn more and more about all the complexity that exists, but even still you'll never be able to honestly conclude anything precise on all that. Even with all sides being wise, the flow of arguments and counter arguments will never end. Perhaps that's why there's something called religion. Peace.

Beautifully explained!ğŸ‰

First of all, there is a difference between rights and recognition. Women in today s world do have more rights (speaking in a Western region context). Countries such as Canada, US, NZ, AU, have more rights for women comparatively. It is also a fact that men and women are NOT THE SAME AND WILL NEVER BE THE SAME because of the concept of their creation. (i.e. Adam was created before Eve, and Eve was created to provide comfort and company to Adam). Because woman is the gender responsible for carrying a future generation, these countries recognize their rights and de facto rights were given to the mother (as long as the mother is proven to provide good care). So it is proven that literate society with intellectual understanding do consider human rights when it comes to women.

The argument now is on the equality basis. So all I can say is that men are not privileged and have to face the same kind of obstacles as women when it comes to leadership positions in society with respect to social, political, and ethical culture. One must prove themselves with determination. 

In my personal opinion, men and women are physically different, but psychologically, intellectually, and aesthetically are very much capable of standing equally right next to men. The differentiation point is the mindset of making a choice.  "Normative Conformity"  is not being imposed on someone, yet it's that individual's choice to have the need to fit-in and that's not a societal issue. I consider it a personal issue. Issue that one does not have enough confidence to stand up for him or her self, issue that one is waiting for the society to make choices for him or herself. these are the issue in today's world where all the "so-called Feminists" are rising up and voicing out ridiculous concerns about women not having basic human rights. The narrative is so convoluted that women today are not abusing it and turning a legitimate concept into bullying men. Before even talking about Women are not have equal rights in today's world we should add more context to which region are talking about, analyze whether its a women's rights issue or human rights issue (which includes similar issues for men), and whether that region has judicial regulation to safe guard these human rights. if all the answers are YES, and still there are issues, than that's the criminal offense instead of just "women equality".

Being a long time viewer of your channel, I think this will be one of the very few videos where I think you didn't put out the whole picture about the voting issue.
Men got the right to vote before women because men were subject to military conscription. If you elected a representative to represent you in the government, that representative could then vote to send you to war. Men, being the exclusive victims of forced military conscription, were perceived to have more of a say and a right. But this privilege also came with corresponding responsibilities, such as the obligation to serve in the military and potentially sacrifice their lives on the battlefield. That's how men gained the right to vote before women did.
And I don't think a single woman would come forward today to die on the battlefield, if there's a World War III.

Every rational and wise person supports feminism. Women should be given equal rights. It is ok to give equal rights and opportunities in education, job , sports etc. The issue arises when women start asking men to cook food and wash vessels. As a man I feel that we have been doing the harder things and evolved with different capabilities. For example if my job is to be a construction worker lifting heavy things, I cannot switch roles with my wife. She would rather feel safe and better to stay home and cook for the family.  Women are good at taking care of kids, men aren't. It isn't easy to switch roles and have equal duties for both in that case. Similarly there are many things which only men can do, but women aren't built to do and vice versa.  We need to understand our capabilities and roles and not keep cribbing about it. If there's a couple who work in a software company which doesn't involve any hard labour, then they can share the house chores equally. I would personally prefer my wife to be at home and take care of the kids and  household chores and cook good food for me when I am back from work, rather than both going out to work, having a maid to Cook for us and leaving kids in a daycare center. I think the majority of the women also would prefer the same coz that's an ideal scenario. The problem arises when the husband abuses his rights and suppresses his wife. That's when women feel the need to work and earn money to become independent.

I don't agree with a lot of things in the video.

In nature, men and women have been made different and hence both have got perks and disadvantages in different different conditions/situations. Hence men and women have been made equal by nature.

Eg. A woman is more capable of taking care/nourishing children/family. And men are more capable of being tough and being resourceful for the family. Now bcz of this biological truth, both have pros and cons. Like since woman is supposed to stay at home, she tends to have less 'freedom'. On the other hand man has got 'freedom' but has the responsibility of earning and risk of outside harms.

By artificially giving equal power to women, in reality we are giving more power to women and hence creating inequality.

Eg. By giving freedom and choice of choosing their romantic partners to women, society has taken away most of the power from men to get into a healthy relationship without compromising with his dignity.

I have a very different view from other contemporary views , I am neither a patriarchal nor a feminist, but I rather believe in considering eveybody as human, surely I am an admirer of Mahatma Jyotirao Phule and Savitribai Phule who encouraged Women's education , for me women should demand rights like equal education, equal pay, creation of a safe environment, stopping of crime against women etc., but what I am really against is putting posters and demanding rights like , right to smoke, right to consume alcohol (this actually only benefits the companies producing them), asking for right to have multiple partners etc.I call these things as pseudo-feminism,  infact on the other handI get impressed by how high a girl is educated , I always hate people who marry their girls when young and thus indulge in child marraige , my views is don't consider somebody as  man or woman but as human , and I completely disagree with the man loliness thing, it has more to do with being an extrovert or introvert rather than being a man or a woman , I myself share my problems or worries with my friends and also my friends do the same , infact many of my friends have also shared experiences of even their 'intimate' things, only the difference is that personal or emotional talks between two boys always remain only between two of them and that is why the outside world never knows about it, but personal talks between two girls may not always remain only between two of them.

Whatever you said is definitely correct and the problem is no one understands this. I have often heard this that, "That girl is one of those feminist types", meaning she is a bad person. It is said in this way. Now there is another problem that has raised in India. As of 2024, women do have certain rights that empower them. One such is the dowry law, where the groom's family can be charged for dowry. Now as we know the seriousness of the dowry cases, the law has been made in a way to get swift action in case of a complaint. Adding into that, the law enforcement officials often times harass the accused. So in a false case, this can be a huge issue and this in turn is defaming the whole women empowerment agenda, and the mindset is being pushed to the same, "ladki padh likh legi toh hath se nikal jayegi" mindset. Now this is the same thing you mentioned in your video that, women are also the enemies of feminism. Personal motives and greed is just damaging the reputation of women. (Again, there have be 1000s of incidents of dowry where the grooms family may have even went to an extent to kill the wife, but if 1 women askes for divorce and alimony that is a way bigger issue on social media. Both are wrong according to me. But which one has more engagement on social media? Just see it.) 

Now there is an argument that - What rights men have that women don't? Yes as of 2024, women have all the legal rights that men have. But on the ground level the mindset as not changed. It is very common to hear, "Why are you spending so much on your daughter's education, leave something for her marriage as well." As of right now, the feminists' fight is with patriarchy and not the legal system. The legal system battle has been won for a while now. In the future, I want to see a society where women don't need the extra laws to protect them. When that happens, those alpha males will not have to worry about a women taking away 50% of his net worth.

This is my take and I do not know how many agree:
I am against feminism, the concept that women and men are equal. Women are more precious than men, they need more protection and men should protect them.
A brother should protect his sister, a son should protect his mother, a father should protect his daughter, a boyfriend should protect his girlfriend,  a husband should protect his wife and finally any man should protect any woman.
The sad part about feminism is it is gaslighting women and turning them against men. While there are a minority of animals who call themselves men, majority of men are normal human beings who believe women are human beings just like them, specially the newer generation is more commendable in this regard. 
Those who say women are equal to men are stupid, of course they are physically and mentally different. Women and men are opposites, opposites attract and create a beautiful balance in life.
All we need to do is acknowledge that both men and women are human beings with their differences. 
Human rights and laws should be designed to empower the weaknesses and punish injustice against both men and women. 
Replace feminism and patriarchy with humanism.

In this way, the economic right given by Islam makes the woman so strong that no matter how much the woman is grateful;  While women are completely deprived of these economic rights.

Civil rights

                  Choice of husband: In relation to the choice of husband, Islam has given a large degree of freedom to women.  In connection with marriage, the will of the girls and their permission has been declared essential in every situation.  The Prophet said:

                 A married woman should not be married unless she is consulted, and a virgin should not be married without her permission. (13)

                 If someone has been married in childhood, the girl's will is not included in it when she becomes an adult, then she has the right to reject this marriage, in such a case no one can force her.

                 Yes, if a woman wants to marry a person who is immoral or against her family, then in such a case the saints will definitely intervene.

 Right to eviction

                  Islam has given the right of divorce to the woman, that if the husband is unfaithful and incompetent, the wife can annul the marriage and these rights are granted through the court.

 Right to good society

                 It is commanded in the Qur'an: Be kind to women (Al-Nisa': 19). Therefore, the husband is instructed to treat his wife with kindness and generosity.  There are those who are good towards their wives and treat their families with pleasure and kindness.

The social position of women in the eyes of Islam

                 The social position of women in Islam is so high that it can be inferred from the fact that in the matter of socializing, Allah Ta'ala specifically addresses men and orders that in the matter of socializing with them, "  to be considered "well-known";  So that they behave well in every aspect of society and in everything.  It is said that:

                 (Al-Nisa': 19)
  And live with these women in good company, if you dislike them, then it is possible that you dislike something and Allah will put a lot of good in it.

                  Society means living together, in this sense, Allah Almighty has ordered men to live together with women in the Holy Quran.  The second is that it has been tied to the "known", and living a known life means that one should be very polite and polite in conversation, be gentle and loving in one's words, not be bossy and listen to one thing with attention and  Don't be disrespectful, and don't show any sense of humor. (19)

Right to freedom of opinion

Economic rights

                 Respect in society depends on economic status.  The one who has perfect wealth, people look at him with respect and the one who does not have it, people do not even bother to pass near him, respect is a distant thing.  All the societies and systems of the world kept women economically weak, except Islam, then this economic weakness became the cause of her oppression and poverty.  Western civilization wanted to cure this oppression of women.  And forced the women out of the house and put them to work in factories and other places.  In this way, women earning outside the home became the cause of many other problems, in these situations Islam is the only religion that took the path of moderation.

                 (1) The non-maintenance of a woman is the responsibility of a man in every situation.  If there is a daughter, it is the responsibility of the father.  If it is a sister, it is the responsibility of the brother, if it is a wife, then the husband is obligated to pay for it, and if it is a mother, then its expenses are the responsibility of her son.

            (Al-Baqarah: 236)
 A prosperous man should give sustenance according to his ability and a poor man according to his ability.

                 (2) Dowry: It is obligatory on the man to pay the woman's right to dowry.  Allah Ta'ala says in the Holy Qur'an:

                 (Al-Nisaa: 4)
 Pay the dowry of women with pleasure, if they forgive you some part of it with their pleasure, then eat it with pleasure and relish.

                 (3) Inheritance: According to some religions, women have no right to inherit;  But unlike these religions and societies, Islam gave women a regular share in inheritance.  (Al-Nisa': 11) That is, a woman's share is half that of a man, (the reason for which is not the occasion to explain) in the same way, she is entitled to a regular inheritance from her father, husband, children, and other close relatives.

                 Islam addresses both men and women and has made everyone bound by worship, ethics and Shari'ah, which is not possible without knowledge. The passage discusses the equality of men and women within institutions, arguing that without proper leadership, institutions cannot function effectively. It suggests that just as in an institution with two men, one must be chosen as the leader, similarly, if a woman is part of the institution, she too can be chosen as the leader. Furthermore, it proposes that in such cases, men should accept the leadership of the woman to ensure the proper functioning of the institution. The analogy is extended to marriage, considering it as an institution that brings families together and requires the proper conduct of all parties involved for its stability. The passage concludes by suggesting that Islam has prescribed marriage as a system that has been in place since the beginning of humanity and is ordained by God for the proper management of human relationships.

In recent times, it has been accepted as fact, on a purely academic level, that fundamental, inborn differences do exist between men and women. Researchers have found greater dependence and docility in very young girls, greater autonomy and activity in boys. One such experiment was conducted in the U.S. When a barrier was set up to separate youngsters from their mothers, boys tried to knock it down; girls cried helplessly. There are personality differences between the sexes too. Some distinctions turn up remarkably early. At New York University, for example, researchers have found that a female infant stops sucking a bottle and looks up when someone comes into the room; a male pays no attention to the visitor. Scientific researchers almost unanimously agree that hormones help determine how people feel and act. Thus the male-female differences are entirely genetic in nature. The passivity found in women is due to the particular nature of the female hormones. Differences between male and female hormones exist from birth: they are not acquired later, as would be the case if they stemmed from differences in environment. It is this fact of nature on which Islamic teachings have been based. Because of womenâ€™s delicate constitution, Islam teaches men to be gentle with them. " A Closer Look " 

Western women have come out of the house and into the marketplace in full force, but a closer look raises the question as to how much of this is â€œliberation,â€ and, even more important, what is its cost in human and social terms for women and for society. In 1990, 53.5 million women, or 58 percent of all American women, were in the labor force â€” three fourths of them working full time. From 1975 to 1990, 20 million women had been added to the work force. Labor force participation of all women between 16 and 65 years of age rose dramatically, but the steepest increase was among married women with a husband present in the home. In 1990, nearly 60 percent of all married mothers with children under six years of age were working outside the home. In 1980 less than 20 percent of married mothers with toddlers under three years of age were fulltime workers; by 1990 more than 33 percent of these mothers were in the work force. Though women have made substantial advances in professional, technical and administrative-management occupational areas, they are still overwhelmingly employed in the administrative support occupations, including clerical and secretarial jobs, and services (such as sales-girls, waitresses, hairdressers, etc.). In 1975, only 5.2 percent of employed females were in executive, administrative or management occupations, whereas by 1990 this had grown to 11.1 percent. Similarly, in 1975, 13.2 percent of employed women worked in the traditional professions (i.e., as physicians, lawyers, registered nurses), and 2.7 percent worked in technical and related professions but, by 1990 this had increased to 15.1 percent and 3.5 percent respectively. In 1975, 63.7 percent of female employees were confined to four areas â€” namely, sales, administrative support, private household and other service occupations. In 1990 58.6 percent of employed women still worked in these fields. So, although women in America are now 13.9 percent of all police and detectives, 19.3 percent of all physicians, 36 percent of all computer programmers, 43.5 percent of all manufacturing assemblers, 44.3 percent of all financial managers and 51.5 percent of all bus drivers, they are also 99 percent of all secretaries, 89.2 percent of all textile sewing machine operators, 84.8 percent of all health aides and 80.8 percent of all waitresses. Among government employees, though women are a minority at the highest grade levels, their representation there has been increasing sharply. For instance, in 1982, 22.4 percent of the employees in Grades 11-12 and only 9.7 percent in Grades 13-15, were women. By 1988, 31.9 percent of Grades 11-12 employees and 15.9 percent of Grades 13-15 employees were women. Still, the bulk of women in government employment are concentrated at the six lowest grades. In 1982, and still in 1988, fully 75 percent of the employees in the lowest six levels were women. Though the pay gap between men and women has closed somewhat, and more so in some occupations than in others, discrimination in earnings and benefits remains pervasive. In 1980 women earned, on average, 64 cent for every dollar earned by men in the United States; by 1990 it was 72 cents. In certain areas, such as technical, sales, administrative support and service jobs, the male-female wage gap narrowed in recent years as much because of declines in menâ€™s salaries (due to recession condition) as of increases in womenâ€™s wages. As of 1989, women were still more likely than men to be working at minimum wage jobs. Female workers were less likely than males to have employer or union-sponsored pension plans in 1987 (but between 1980 and 1987 the proportion of male workers with pension plans dropped by 6 percentage points). In spite of the fact that nearly half the American work force consists of women, neither maternity/paternity leave nor childcare support was by any means the norm in American firms, even in 1989. At that time, no more than 3 percent of medium and large size firms, on average, provided paid maternity leave, and this went down to 2 percent for small firms (with less than 100 employees). In 1988, more than 60 percent of American children under age 18 had working mothers, but as far as childcare assistance is concerned, no more than 10 percent of firms of all sizes provided any real benefits or support for childcare. However, 35-45 percent of all firms did provide flexible schedules and flexible leave times for parents with young children. â€œFlexitimeâ€ notwithstanding, in 1987 6.2 million working mothers in America paid for childcare. Of these 750,000 had incomes at or below the poverty line, and for them childcare expenses ate up 20 percent of their income. Though mothers with children under age 21 and no father present are entitled to government child support, often they do not get it at all or do not get the full amount. Closely related to the issue of womenâ€™s earnings and benefits in the fact that between 1970 and 1989 the number of women workers of age 16 and above holding multiple jobs increased by almost 400 percent â€” from 636,000 to more than 3 million. Women who worked more than one job in 1989 were more likely than men to be doing so because the additional earnings were necessary to meet regular household expenses.

" Unnatural Equality " 

Selected readings from the Qurâ€™an were prepared in English by the English Orientalist, Edward William Lane, and were first published in London in book form in 1843. In his foreword, Lane wrote that â€œthe fatal point in Islam was the degradation of woman.â€ Since then this remark has been regularly taken up as a stick with which to beat Islam. In fact, whenever Islamic affairs were mentioned, it became such a common observation, that not only the enemies of Islam, but also relatively fair-minded writers such as the historian, J.M. Roberts, who did justice to Islam in pointing out its virtues, mentioned it as if it were an established fact. We have shown in detail, at another point in this book, that this allegation is entirely baseless. The facts are quite the reverse. Islam has, in actual fact, raised the status of woman. If the truth were told, womanâ€™s degradation has come about at the hands of two major civilizations, one ancient and polytheistic, the other modern and atheistic. The former has been culpable both in theory and in practice, while the latter has been so in practice, despite itâ€™s theorizing to the contrary. We must never lose sight of the fact that what governed the ethics and lifestyles of ancient polytheistic civilizations were myths. Certain highly fanciful, but obviously baseless suppositions were believed in as truths, and all aspects of human existence were subordinated to them. For instance, ancient man regarded certain natural phenomena, such as the sun and the moon, with the awe of ignorance, and venerated them as deities. Conversely, he supposed certain other phenomena to be inferior, therefore, undeserving of respect. It was into the latter category that women fell, possibly because menstruation and their inability to fight alongside their men folk were interpreted in an adversely superstitious manner. Woman was regarded as the inferior sex and, therefore, deserving of degrading treatment by men. Modern western civilization has hardly produced a better result in ostensibly exalting the status of women. It may have pronounced men and women equal in every respect and decreed that all work that can be done by a man can be done by a woman too: it may have encouraged women to come out of their homes and try to find a position equal to a manâ€™s in every department of life (hence the slogan, â€œDonâ€™t make coffee, make policyâ€); but, in practice, this concept of equality has done more to degrade women than any traditional view could have done. The next chapter deals with this topic in detail. What is the reason then for this state of affairs? The reason, to put it briefly, is the erroneous concept of absolute equality in western countries. For example, equality between men is held to be an indisputable fact. But if this equality between men is taken to mean that in every field every man can compete with every other man, the upholder of such an unnatural concept should be able to take an Einstein to a boxing ring and expect him to put up a good fight against the heavyweight champion. Conversely he would also expect the boxer to be able to hold his own while presiding over international, scientific conferences. This may seem laughable, but that is what absolute equality would mean. The Einstein who was at the top of the list in university or science conferences would be seen as a sadly inferior person in a bout with a boxer and the boxer would be completely out of his depth at the conference table. It is clear that applying this rule of equality would result in disaster. True equality mean equality not in the workplace but in status. Human equality does not mean that every man should be engaged in the same work as everyone else. It means rather that every man should be looked upon with the same respect, and should be able to expect the same treatment, legally and morally. The error into which the West has fallen is its attempt to establish an unnatural equality in the workplace for men and women. The result is as might have been expected: the greatest inequality in human history has developed between men and women. If men and women are of two different sexes, it is because they were created to serve separate purposes. Place them in their respective fields and they will be equally successful, although in different ways. Place both men and women in the same field, and the women will fail to excel: the men will do better due to their natural abilities. As a result, the women will suffer a fall in status vis-Ã -vis the men. Inspired by false notions of equality, a certain country girl once fled her home to seek an independent life in a city intending to make money as men do. She failed, however, to find a place in the world of men. What remained at her disposal now was her femininity. This she traded for an independent life. This independent life was not, however, gained by securing â€œequalityâ€ in social life; it was gained rather by having condescended to become the plaything of men. Somewhat similar, but on a larger scale, has been the case of western women. The West encouraged women to come out of their homes to earn like men. They did so only to find that it was impossible to have an independent life by working like men in the outside world. The only alternative available to them to making money was their femininity. Like the country girl who fled her home, they had to sell their femininity in the market place. Such unnatural and immoral acts failed to give women an equal status. This resulted rather in the creation of innumerable new problems. One of them is pornography, which is not a separate problem in itself, but the inevitable result of unrestricted freedom having given way to licence.

" Women in Modern Civilisation " 

Where modern western man fell deeply into error, was in his blind acceptance of the concept of the equality of the sexes without giving due consideration of what equality â€” in its best sense -â€” ought to mean, or what in practice it entails. According to modern thinking, giving equal status to women meant bringing them out of their homes and standing them face to face with men in all facets of life without any regard for the practical and moral problems which might ensue. Islam, on the other hand, defines separate roles, and, therefore, separate spheres of work for men and women, since it is natural and realistic to do so. The other great error made by modern western thinkers was to assume that a role which was separate and different, and played out in other than traditionally masculine strongholds, was necessarily of trifling importance â€” in short, inferior. As such, the West concluded that in giving a separate role to woman Islam gives them an inferior position. Conversely, since it is held in the West (in theory) that women must be given a place in all masculine spheres it is also concluded that the West gives her a superior position. So modern man imagines that his feminine counterpart has, in actuality, been accorded a superior position. But let us examine what, in fact, is the state of womenâ€™s affairs. In the societies of the West, which have attained a high level of material development, theory has yet to be put into practice, and men and women still live and work in their own very separate domains. The status of women is, in practice, almost the same as it was in ancient times, there still being mutually exclusive divisions into male and female spheres, with the corresponding attitudes still very much in evidence. If this were not so, what need would there be for â€œwomenâ€™s lib?â€ Fourteen hundred years ago, Islam launched a much-needed â€œwomenâ€™s libâ€ movement, whose purpose was to free women from artificial curbs, and to give them the position which any normal human being should have in society. (One instance, for example is to give them a share in family property). This movement raised their status without any sacrifice of femininity or traditional values, and without creating any perversion in society. Having launched its movement under the guidance of revelation, its Islamic exponents were in no doubt as to what limits should be set to societal change. The West, however, in its preoccupation with modernity, plunged headlong into experimentation with the old order of values, sweeping away traditional moral precepts and â€œrestrictiveâ€ conventions. All of this was done under the banners of â€œreason,â€ â€œempiricism,â€ â€œlogic,â€ â€œliberalism,â€ and so on, but, in actual fact, the whole â€œliberationâ€ movement has been swamped in a welter of emotion, creating a number of social problems.

" Women's Status in Islam " 

In ancient times, thanks to the unreasoning and unreasonable approach fostered by superstition, speculation and other forms of irrational thinking, woman came to be considered inferior, one distressing result of which was that she was deprived, among many other things, of the right to inherit property. She was not even entitled to a share of family property. How great an incapacitating factor this was may be judged from the neglect and degrading treatment which women had to suffer for centuries. It was not until the advent of Islam, that, for the first time in the history of mankind, women were given their due legal rights over property. The famous historian J.M. Roberts writes: Its coming was in many ways revolutionary. It kept women, for example, in an inferior position, but gave them legal rights over property not available to women in many European countries until the nineteenth century. Even the slave had rights and inside the community of the believers there were no castes nor inherited status. This revolution was rooted in a religion which -â€” like that of the Jews â€” was not distinct from other sides of life, but embraced them all.5 The same point has been made about ancient India by a retired Chief Justice of the Delhi Court, Mr. Rajindar Sachar: ... Historically, Islam had been very liberal and progressive in granting property rights to women. It is a fact that there were no property rights given to Hindu women until 1956, when the Hindu Code Bill was passed, whereas Islam had granted these rights to Muslim women over 1400 years ago.6 This is not, however, just a matter of anteriority. What is significant is that, in granting women equal status and their proper rights, Islam set up an important precedent which had as far-reaching m effect on the civilization of the times as western civilization has lad on the world of today. If Islam was able to accomplish such an â€˜evolution in human affairs, it was because it did not remain just a philosophical creed, but went on to conquer most parts of the inhabited world of the times. In the world of today, even those commentators who generously acknowledge the virtues of Islam often repeat the dictum that Islam has relegated women to an inferior status. But to say that Islam gives women a share in property and then to say at the same time that Islam has degraded women is contradictory. From ancient times till today, the question of inheritance has been the most important social issue, and might well be considered the sole criterion of status in society. Entitling women to have a share in property, contrary to the custom of the time, is a clear proof that Islam had no desire to degrade them. Had this been so, the first demonstration of this desire would have been to deprive them of their share in property, a correct and justifiable practice according to the traditions of the times. It is interesting to see the reverse side of the coin as presented by a recent convert to Islam, namely, the English pop singer, Cat Stevens, now known as Yusuf Islam. Asked by a Jewish woman how he intended to deal with the problem of Islamâ€™s â€œdegradationâ€ of women, he said that he had not actually made a study of womenâ€™s status in Islam, but that for his own part, he had, since his conversion, asked his mother to come and stay with him and that he loved looking after her. His relations with his wife had also considerably improved. In its assessment of the status of women, the western mind has made the same error as was made by ancient man: it has formed opinions based on irrational beliefs. This accounts for latter-day distortions of thought regarding women in the advanced western countries and for the resultant grave distortion in the concept of women.

" Baneful Effects of Deviation " 

Any deviation from the divine balance established by God leads to chaos and confusion. It is, therefore, laid down in the Qurâ€™an that no changes should be made in the balance God has created by means of His laws of reform.17 One example of universal balance is the fixity of the distance between the sun and earth (about 90 million miles). This distance is extremely balanced, ensuring a whole range of temperatures on earth which is favorable to the continuance of the human species. If this balance were upset in any way, it would result in all kinds of disasters. For instance, if the distance between the sun and the earth were reduced by half, temperatures would rise to such extremes, that everything and everyone on the surface of the earth would be reduced to ashes. There would be no possibility of life existing in any form whatsoever. The same applies to the girth of our planet. Its present circumference is about 25,000 miles, but if this were reduced by half, the pull of its gravity would be so weakened that we should all go flying off into space. If, on the contrary, the circumference were doubled, the effect of gravity would be so overwhelming that all growth would cease. Man would be reduced to the size of a mouse and a mouse would be little bigger than an ant. The unparalleled balance that exists on earth is aptly illustrated by the strange example of the insects which, unlike human beings, do not possess lungs, but breathe through tubes. When insects grow large the tubes cannot grow in ratio to the increasing size of the body of the insect. Hence there never has been an insect more than a few inches long with a slightly longer wing spread. Because of the mechanism of their structure and their method of breathing, there never could be an insect of great size. This limit in their growth held all insects in check and prevented them from dominating the world. If this physical check had not been provided, man could not exist. Imagine a man meeting a hornet as big as a lion or a spider equally large.18 Of course, the notion of order in the world has periodically been called into question. A certain western writer has suggested that the gravitational pull of the earth is far greater than is absolutely essential, hence the difficulty one experiences in carrying even a weight of ten kilos. Had it been less, he points out; we should have been able to walk about, carrying a weight with ease. But this objection is ill-founded. It is entirely due to gravity having the pull that it does, that our homes remain firmly fixed to the ground. Had it been less, they would have flown about like kites, and civilization, as we know it would hardly have been possible. It is fortunate that the order of the universe is not in the hands of men. If it were, we should experience intermittent tampering with the immutable laws of nature. Gravity would wax and wane, the earth would move nearer to or further from the sun and, on the pretext that nature had been cruel to insects in fixing the size of their breathing tubes, the said creatures would be encouraged to grow to elephantine proportions, thus filling the whole earth with them. None of these developments would, however, be encouraging to the human species! Luckily, man cannot effect such changes in the universe, since he has no power over its ordering. But he is free to act as he wills in his own world, and the result has been chaos on a grand scale. The extremes to which he has gone are thus referred to in the Qurâ€™an: â€œEvil appears on land and sea as a result of the (evil) which menâ€™s hands have done.â€

" Law of Balance "

Now let us examine this divine law. In the words of the Qurâ€™an it is the law of balance: â€œHe raised the heaven on high and set the balance that you might not transgress the balance. Give just weight and full measure.â€15 The universe is not composed of just one item. It is rather a collection of highly disparate elements. Besides this, each and every one of its components is in motion. Not a single constituent, from the minutest atom to the most gigantic galaxy, can ever for a second remain static. For the precise functioning of this infinitely complex assemblage of moving components, limits in space and time had to be applied so that the different parts did not come into conflict with each other. God, therefore â€” besides creating all these things â€” established a systematic balance between them. This principle is known as the â€œLaw of Nature.â€ Similarly, in the human world â€” also a vast assemblage of disparate individuals â€” everyone is in motion. And in order that each should continue on his lifeâ€™s journey without colliding with his fellow men, it was likewise necessary to establish boundaries, both moral and physical, for all human beings without exception: a balance had to be struck so that there should be no clash between individuals or societies. It is, indeed, this law of nature which has been revealed to humanity through the medium of the prophets. Godâ€™s will on this subject is recorded in the Qurâ€™an: â€œWe have sent our Messengers with clear signs and brought down with them scriptures and the scales of justice so that men might deal with fairness.â€16 That is to say that God sent a balance of justice in the form of a book through His prophets. This book was supported by arguments and evidence so that people could believe in its authenticity and would not hesitate to order their lives according to this balance, that is, the just law. While the law of balance is inherent in the rest of creation, for man, it has been provided externally through the revelations of this divine book.

" ORDER OF NATURE "

Sculpture is an ancient form of art. There is, no doubt, an obvious resemblance between living beings and statues, but if someone were to presume that the concerns of human beings were the same as those of statues and began to study man under the heading of sculpture, what would be the outcome? This method of study would certainly lead to strange conclusions. A carved image has no need of food and drink; therefore, the student of sculpture would naturally assume that arrangements to this effect were not necessary for man either. He would proceed to the assumption that if a statue can be locked inside a room for any length of time, so could a man be put inside a locked room for years without anyone having to worry about him. During the time of the former President of Egypt, Jamal Abdun Nasir, an ancient statue of Abu Simbel, 20 meters high and firmly fixed in the rocks, had to be removed from its place to make way for the construction of a huge dam. This work, undertaken between 1964 and 1966, necessitated the use of special machines which could cut the statue into several pieces so that they could be shifted to a safer place, and then reassembled. Now, on this parallel, the student who views man as a statue, can also, as part of some scheme, start chopping up the human body. Of course, there is no sculptor in this world who would do such a thing. But in another department, that of education, such experts have come into being in modern times as are experimenting with man as if he were a statue, and doing everything to him that could be done to a statue. This branch of knowledge is called â€œanthropology.â€ This field of study began at the turn of the 19th century. In the light of data collected on external information regarding the conditions of ancient man, his beliefs, customs, traditions, certain conclusions about human beings in general were arrived at. Religion naturally came within this field of study, necessitating the collection of information on the religions practised by different tribes and communities. Thus a list of the customs which went under the name of religion was produced. A natural outcome of this method of study was that religion came to be regarded as a social phenomenon. That is to say, religion was presented as something which had evolved out of the influences of human myths, customs and social conditions. Religion is essentially a divine truth (a commandment of God), but thanks to the anthropologistsâ€™ particular method of study, it has been reduced to a mere artifact of historical accretion. The greatest harm done to religion by this method of study is that in modern times it has been shorn of its credibility, and reduced to insignificance, whereas, as the commandment of Godâ€™s religion it had an unassailable authenticity, because it possessed divine credibility in its own right. Every religious statement was accepted as the ultimate statement of a superior being and, as such, worthy of being adhered to. Conversely, when religion is regarded merely as a social phenomenon, all its credibility is dissipated. This can be compared to relegating the science of chemistry to the position of alchemy, or to equating astronomy with astrology. The fact is that this method of study, when applied to religion, is totally wrong. It turns a reality into a non-reality. It is to accord human status to something which is essentially divine. To understand the reality of religion let us peruse this verse of the Qurâ€™an: â€œAre they seeking a religion other than Godâ€™s when every soul in heaven and earth has submitted to Him, willingly or by compulsion? To Him they shall all return.â€14 According to this verse, the religion which God desires man to adopt in his daily living is the same divine law which God has imposed upon the entire universe. Religion is the name of this same universal law.

" THE WILLINGNESS OF WOMEN "

The presence of a greater number of women in a society is not the only prerequisite for polygamy. It is, in addition, compulsory that the woman who is the object of the manâ€™s choice should be willing to enter into the married state. This willingness on the womanâ€™s part is a must before a marriage can be lawful in Islam. It is unlawful to marry a woman by force. There is no example in the history of Islam where a man has been allowed to force a woman into marriage. The Prophet Muhammadâ€™s own view that â€œan unmarried girl should not be married until her permission has been takenâ€6 had been recorded by both Bukhari and Muslim. â€˜Abdullah ibn â€˜Abbas, one of the Prophetâ€™s Companions and a commentator on the Qurâ€™an, narrates the story of a girl who came to the Prophet complaining that her father had her married off against her wishes. The Prophet gave her the choice of either remaining within the bonds of wedlock or of freeing herself from them.7 Another such incident narrated by â€˜Abdullah ibn â€˜Abbas concerns a woman called Burairah and her husband, Mughith, who was a black slave. â€˜Abdullah ibn â€˜Abbas tells the story as if it were all happening before his very eyes: â€œMughith is following Burairah through the paths of Medina. He is crying and his tears are running down his beard. Seeing him, the Prophet said to me, â€˜O â€˜Abbas, are you not surprised at Mughithâ€™s love for Burairah and Burairahâ€™s hate for Mughith?â€™ Then the Prophet said to Burairah, â€˜I wish you would take him back.â€™ Burairah said to the Prophet, â€˜Is that a command?â€™ The Prophet replied, â€˜No, it is only a recommendation.â€™ Then Burairah said, â€˜I donâ€™t need your recommendation.â€™â€8 There was an interesting case of polygamy which took place during the Caliphate of â€˜Umar ibn al-Khattab. A certain widow, Umm Aban bint â€˜Utbah had four suitors for marriage. All four â€” â€˜Umar ibn al-Khattab, â€˜Ali ibn abi Talib, Zubayr and Talhah â€” were already married. Umm Aban accepted the proposal of marriage made by Talhah and, of course, refused the other three, whereupon she was married to Talhah.9 This happened in Medina, the capital of the Islamic State. Among the rejected suitors was the reigning Caliph. But no one expressed even surprise or dismay, the reason being that in Islam, a woman is completely free to make her own decisions. This is a right that no one can take away from her-â€” not even the ruler of the day. These incidents show that the Islamic commandments giving permission to marry up to four women does not mean having the right to seize four women and shut them up inside oneâ€™s home. Marriage is a matter of mutual consent. Only that woman can be made a second or a third wife who is willing to be so. And when this matter rests wholly on the willingness of the woman, there is no cause for objection. The present age gives great importance to freedom of choice. This value is fully supported by Islamic law. On the other hand, the upholders of â€œfeminismâ€ want to turn freedom of choice into restriction of choice.

I think women in India are much ahead in terms of equal rights than western countries, here's why - 
1. Many Hindu Gods are women
2. Our 2 main mythology stories are around the dignity of women.
3. Shivaji maharaj where created any built by there mother - Jijau mata. (In 1600)
4. We had tararani Bai (from Kolhapur) who fought against Mughals. ( 1700s)
5. We have Jhasi ki rani, who fought in war (1800)
6. We have Savitribai phule, for made school for girls ( 1800)
7. India had women prime minister - Indira Gandhi for 8-9 years, and 2 women presidents - Pratibha Patil and drapati Marmo.

All above shows that India has always valued women, from very past till present.

Whereas compared to Western countries, there is no History of women fighting in war. US did not had a single women President so far. 

Overall, India should have support for women in terms of equal rights, but western countries need more feminism than Indians.

Here is the simple magic formula she divulged to her American sisters so that they may lead successful married lives. â€œBe nice to your husband, stop nagging him and understand his needs.â€ In less than a year this book sold three million copies. WHITHER WOMEN'S LIBS ?

From the 12th to the 16th of January, 1987, a conference was held in Vigyan Bhavan, New Delhi, in which philosophers, scientists, writers and artists from 15 countries participated. This five-day conference was arranged by the Government of India on the topic, â€œTowards New Beginnings.â€ Many distinguished ladies of the western world, who have now grown old, were among those who participated. They had spent all their lives working for Womenâ€™s Lib, but their mood was one of frustration. The Indian Express cites Germaine Greer of Australia as a case in point: They are feminists of different hues â€” Ms. Germaine Greer, the outspoken, aggressive writer from Australia, and Ms. Gisele Halimi, a Tunisian-born lawyer who spearheaded the womenâ€™s movement in France along with Simone de Beauvoir and others. But both voice a concern that is troubling feminists in the West today â€” Whither womenâ€™s lib? Ms. Greer seems more mellow today: the fire that raged in The Female Eunuch is strangely missing. â€œThe movement has solved some problems and left us with a different set of problems,â€ exclaimed Ms. Greer. â€œPerhaps the problem was that we didnâ€™t take our mothers with us. We left them behind, found them antiquated. And now that many of us are mothers ourselves with teenaged daughters, perhaps we understand our mothers better.â€2 â€œThe West has no answers to the problems of inequality between sexes,â€ says the internationally acclaimed writer Germaine Greer. The erroneous belief of western women that the females in veils are unequal and the ones with make-up minus the head-cover are free and liberated has to be rejected. Referring to the prevalence of â€œwife-beatingâ€ even in the so-called civilized West, she asks, how about the unequal treatment meted out to females in the U.S. and England in the areas of wages and jobs? Well, one-fourth of the crimes in England emanate from violence against women. The man-woman relationship understood in the West as an extension of role-models is the primary cause of strain in the sexual relationships. All the western women identify themselves with the bahu â€” the bride â€” forgetting that the mother-in-law and the sister-in-law are also the specific role models to be played by females. She feels that child bearing for a woman is a unique investment: â€œThe joys of motherhood fill the blanks that cannot be satiated in the specific husband-wife role models.â€ Known for her non-conformist and non-traditional views, Ms. Greer advocates â€œcoitus interruptusâ€ in the area of birth-control: â€œThe array of occlusive devices, spermicidal creams, quinine pessaries, douches, syringes, abortifacient pills and rubber goods of all shapes and sizes are the ill-effects of a growing consumer-culture. These have achieved nothing but added strain in the sexual relationships.â€3 Ms. Halimi, is more frank. â€œIt is a bad time for the womenâ€™s movementâ€ she admitted. â€œIt is down at the moment and we are trying to find the reasons for it. Perhaps we got everything women wanted too fast â€” contraception, abortion, and divorce. And the problems that face women today are not strong enough to give the movement new force and strength.â€ Women have very specific values and morals. â€œThey have a different view of humanity. I am not saying that it is better than that of men, but it is different. And women have to prove that they are women, and not men,â€ she emphasized.4 According to religious teaching, the womanâ€™s â€œrole modelâ€ was that of mother and housekeeper. She was meant to bear and rear children, and manages the home. The modern role model is that of the busy woman executive, functioning on an equal footing with men in every sphere of the professional world. Years of experiment have shown that the latter role is unrealistic. In their old age, the same western women, who had fervently advocated the new role model, are the very ones who are now asking for a return to the status quo ante. Does this leave any room for doubt about the superiority of the role model postulated by religion?

This is the result of deliberately ignoring the fact that when God created men and women, He laid down rules for their relationship with each other: on reaching a sufficiently mature stage of development, they were to marry, have children and, by a process of mutual co-operation, make a home in which to bring up those children, thus providing a stable base for the progress of mankind. But western modernity became so preoccupied with the concept of freedom that it dispensed with the kind of bonds which held men and women together in a healthy family relationship. The resulting disregard for the institution of marriage gave birth to various kinds of evils in western society, as may be judged from the above-mentioned examples. The free mixing of men and women, with the sexual liberation it implies, is wholly against nature. In matters of sex, a woman prefers a single partner. Chhapris are a caste-oppressed community of people who made or mended chhappars, temporary roofs. However, the word has in recent years become a pejorative for someone who tries hard to be flamboyant. Feminism is not the solution, even though i am a Pregressive Leftist i am not a feminist, because I don't think making both men and women equal would ever work, because as long as thier is a distinction made by society based on sex, their will be discrimination. Its like doing apartheid and believing both white and black people are equal, if we believed all people are equal, we wouldn't have came up with segregating people based on skin colour.

Because if society believes that sex is important enough that there should be two seperate catagories of people based on it, there will be assumptions and roles being thrusted upon these sets of people.  In reality there is nothing as a men or a women, these are just social constructs(must read on social constructs), also known as make-beliefs, also known as 'bhram' in Indian culture, we are told from the age we are born that we are a boy or a girl, solely based on our sex. we are not born girls or boys, we were told to be boys and girls. Gender is social construct and people are born with different sexes, same as people are born with different colours.

There are many other differences between people, but society makes no distinctions based on them, as you mentioned too. Its doesn't matter if you think sex is important enough to base segregation on. And i think we all as a society have came far enough to believe that there shouldn't be discrimination based on what you are born as at birth, be it colour, bloodline, or sex.

What i think and Many Gender Abolitionists like me think, is the solution is that we abolish gender, we are not segregated based on our sex, we are who we choose to be. We take moral responsibilities based on what role we choose to take, If we abolish gender, we are just people with different sexual organs, no one is a man, no one is a women, we are just people. Because gender as it might seem, is not something fundamental to us, societies construct them and we have abolished many things that society constructed before and at that time, those things felt like they are fundamental to world, but they were not and we progressed.

If we want equality we need to get rid of Gender as a whole.

I am a girl from grade 8th and I want to join the Indian Army. More specifically Infantry which is currently not for women because of many valid reasons. I do agree! But why not let capable women join? Women who are capable of going through that level of mental and physical strain should be allowed to join the Combat Arm. When I put forward this point in society, people called me a feminist and when I show even a spark of ambition, people around me say"Ghar bhi toh sambhalna padega. Posting door ho gayi toh bacchon ko kaun dekhega?" (You will have to look after the house as well. If you will get posted far away from home, who will look after the children?) Boys in my class mocked me as a feminist. I didn't get the true essence of what is feminism and I took it as an insult as girls and boys alike said it in a disgusted way. People like Dhruv Rathee and Emma Watson enlighten everyone about this. People need to understand that feminism is not synonymous with women hating men. You have explained it beautifully. Hats off!! Now I can wear the "feminist" tag with pride. I hope to serve my motherland with valour while being shoulder to shoulder with my male counterparts. I hope the Indian Govt. and society are enlightened and supportive of this by the time I'll be eligible to join. I know that posting this comment might brew up controversies but I want each and everyone to know that afterall, in the eyes of God everyone is equal and that gender equality works both ways. Let's make this world a better place to live and do our part. JAI HIND!

" PRINCIPLE OF DIVISION OF LABOUR "

Within the social framework, however, Islam â€” to the extent that it is both natural and practical â€” has adopted the division of labor in respect of the sexes, the manâ€™s field of activity being basically external to the home, while the womanâ€™s is domestic. This division, however, has never been intended as a form of discriminatory treatment. Its main purpose has always been to preserve the distinctive characteristics of both sexes, while deploying their respective talents and skills in the most socially useful manner. This enables both sexes to make the best use of their innate capabilities without causing any undue disruption in the family or in society. In modem parlance, this is a form of managerial optimization rather than sexual discrimination. For this principle to be effective, the spheres of activity of men and women have had to be quite different and, of course, separate from each other. That is to say that the manâ€™s field of activity is in the outside world, while the womanâ€™s is in the home. This traditional distinction has been so often cited by feminists as an inhibiting factor in womenâ€™s lives that the true meaning of equality has been lost sight of. After all, it will be the very same virtues in thought, word and deed which will be prerequisites for both sexes to enter Paradise. If the qualities of piety, humility, honesty, patience and compassion are demanded of men, they will in like measure be demanded of women. The fact that men and women function in different spheres has no bearing whatsoever on the ultimate equality â€” equality in the eyes of God.
